volume i departmental ditty and other verse. 
i have eat your bread and salt i have drink your water and wine the death ye die i have watch beside and the life that ye lead be mine. 
be there aught that i do not share in vigil or toil or ease one joy or woe that i do not know dear heart across the sea. 
i have write the tale of our life for a shelter people s mirth in jest guise but ye be wise and ye know what the jest be worth. 
general summary. 
we be very slightly change from the semi ape who range india s prehistoric clay. whoso draw the long bow run his brother down you know a we run men down today. 
dowb the first of all his race meet the mammoth face to face on the lake or in the cave steal the steady canoe eat the quarry others slew die and take the fine grave. 
when they scratch the reindeer bone someone make the sketch his own filch it from the artist then even in those early day win a simple viceroy s praise through the toil of other men. 
ere they hew the sphinx s visage favoritism govern kissage even a it doe in this age. 
who shall doubt the secret hide under cheops pyramid be that the contractor do cheops out of several million. or that joseph s sudden rise to comptroller of supply be a fraud of monstrous size on king pharoah s swart civilian. 
thus the artless song i sing do not deal with anything new or never say before. 
a it be in the begin be today official sin and shall be forevermore. 
army headquarter. 
old be the song that i sing old a my unpaid bill old a the chicken that kitmutgars bring men at dak bungalow old a the hill. 
ahasuerus jenkins of the operatic own be dower with a tenor voice of super santley tone. 
his view on equitation be perhaps a trifle queer. he have no seat worth mention but oh. he have an ear. 
he club his wretched company a dozen time a day he use to quit his charger in a parabolic way his method of salute be the joy of all beholder but ahasuerus jenkins have a head upon his shoulder. 
he take two month to simla when the year be at the spring and underneath the deodar eternally do sing. 
he warble like a bulbul but particularly at cornelia agrippina who be musical and fat. 
she control a humble husband who in turn control a dept. where cornelia agrippina s human sing bird be keep from april to october on a plump retain fee supply of course per mensem by the indian treasury. 
cornelia use to sing with him and jenkins use to play. he praise unblushingly her note for he be false a they. so when the wind of april turn the bud rose brown cornelia tell her husband. tom you mustn t send him down. 
they hale him from his regiment which didn t much regret him. they find for him an office stool and on that stool they set him to play with map and catalogue three idle hour a day and draw his plump retain fee which mean his double pay. 
now ever after dinner when the coffeecups be bring ahasuerus waileth o er the grand pianoforte. and thank to fair cornelia his fame hath waxen great and ahasuerus jenkins be a power in the state. 
study of an elevation in indian ink. 
this ditty be a string of lie. but how the deuce do gubbins rise. 
potiphar gubbins c. e. stand at the top of the tree. and i muse in my bed on the reason that lead to the hoist of potiphar g. 
potiphar gubbins c. e. be seven year junior to me. each bridge that he make he either buckle or break and his work be a rough a he. 
potiphar gubbins c. e. be coarse a a chimpanzee. and i can t understand why you give him your hand lovely mehitabel lee. 
potiphar gubbins c. e. be dear to the power that be. for they bow and they smile in an affable style which be seldom accord to me. 
potiphar gubbins c. e. be certain a certain can be of a highly pay post which be claim by a host of senior include me. 
careless and lazy be he greatly inferior to me. 
what be the spell that you manage so well commonplace potiphar g. 
lovely mehitabel lee let me inquire of thee should i have riz to what potiphar be hadst thou be mat to me. 
a legend. 
this be the reason why rustum beg rajah of kolazai drinketh the simpkin and brandy peg maketh the money to fly vexeth a government tender and kind also but this be a detail blind. 
rustum beg of kolazai slightly backward native state lust for a c. s. i. so begin to sanitate. build a jail and hospital nearly build a city drain till his faithful subject all think their ruler be insane. 
strange departure make he then yea department strange still half a dozen englishman help the rajah with a will talk of noble aim and high hint of a future fine for the state of kolazai on a strictly western line. 
rajah rustum hold his peace. lower octroi due a half. organize a state police. purify the. civil staff. settle ce and tax afresh in a very liberal way. cut temptation of the flesh also cut the bukhshi s pay. 
rouse his secretariat to a fine mahratta fury by a hookum hint at supervision of dasturi. turn the state of kolazai very nearly upside down. when the end of may be nigh wait his achievement crown. 
when the birthday honor come sad to state and sad to see stand against the rajah s name nothing more than c. i. e. * * * * *. 
thing be lively for a week in the state of kolazai. even now the people speak of that time regretfully. 
how he disendowed the jail stop at once the city drain. turn to beauty fair and frail get his sens back again. double tax ce all. clear away each new build thana. turn the two lakh hospital into a superb zenana. 
heap upon the bukhshi sahib wealth and honor manifold. clothe himself in eastern garb squeeze his people a of old. 
happy happy kolazai. never more will rustum beg play to catch the viceroy s eye. he prefer the simpkin peg. 
the story of uriah. 
now there be two men in one city. the one rich and the other poor. 
jack barrett go to quetta because they tell him to. he leave his wife at simla on three fourth his monthly screw. jack barrett die at quetta ere the next month s pay he draw. 
jack barrett go to quetta. he didn t understand the reason of his transfer from the pleasant mountain land. the season be september and it kill him out of hand. 
jack barrett go to quetta and there give up the ghost attempt two men s duty in that very healthy post. and mr. barrett mourn for him five lively month at most. 
jack barrett s bone at quetta enjoy profound repose. but i shouldn t be astonish if now his spirit know the reason of his transfer from the himalayan snow. 
and when the last great bugle call adown the hurnal throb when the last grim joke be enter in the big black book of job and quetta graveyard give again their victim to the air i shouldn t like to be the man who send jack barrett there. 
the post that fit. 
though tangle and twist the course of true love this ditty explain no tangle s so tangle it cannot improve if the lover ha brain. 
ere the steamer bore him eastward sleary be engage to marry an attractive girl at tunbridge whom he call my little carrie. 
sleary s pay be very modest. sleary be the other way. who can cook a two plate dinner on eight poor rupee a day. 
long he ponder o er the question in his scantly furnish quarter then propose to minnie boffkin eldest of judge boffkin s daughter. 
certainly an impecunious subaltern be not a catch but the boffkins know that minnie mightn t make another match. 
so they recognise the business and to fee and clothe the bride get him make a something something somewhere on the bombay side. 
anyhow the billet carry pay enough for him to marry a the artless sleary put it. just the thing for me and carrie. 
do he therefore jilt miss boffkin impulse of a base mind. no. he start epileptic fit of an appal kind. 
[of his modus operandi only this much i could gather. pear s shave stick will give you little taste and lot of lather. ]. 
frequently in public place his affliction use to smite sleary with distress vigour always in the boffkins sight. 
ere a week be over minnie weepingly return his ring tell him his unhappy weakness stop all think of marry. 
sleary bore the information with a chasten holy joy epileptic fit don t matter in political employ wire three short word to carrie take his ticket pack his kit bid farewell to minnie boffkin in one last long linger fit. 
four week late carrie sleary read and laugh until she weep mr. boffkin s warn letter on the wretched epilept. 
year by year in pious patience vengeful mr. boffkin sit wait for the sleary baby to develop sleary s fit. 
public waste. 
walpole talk of a man and his price. list to a ditty queer the sale of a deputy act vice resident engineer buy like a bullock hoof and hide by the little tin god on the mountain side. 
by the law of the family circle ti write in letter of brass that only a colonel from chatham can manage the railway of state because of the gold on his breeks and the subject wherein he must pas. because in all matter that deal not with railway his knowledge be great. 
now exeter battleby tring have labour from boyhood to eld on the line of the east and the west and eke of the north and south. many line have he build and survey important the post which he hold. and the lord of the iron horse be dumb when he open his mouth. 
black a the raven his garb and his heresy jettier still hint that railway require lifetime of study and knowledge never clank sword by his side vauban he know not nor drill nor be his name on the list of the men who have pass through the college. 
wherefore the little tin god harry their little tin soul see he come not from chatham jingle no spur at his heel know that nevertheless be he first on the government roll for the billet of railway instructor to little tin god on wheel. 
letter not seldom they write him have the honour to state it would be good for all men if he be lay on the shelf. much would accrue to his bank book an he consent to wait until the little tin god build him a berth for himself. 
special well pay and exempt from the law of the fifty and five even to ninety and nine these be the term of the pact. thus do the little tin god. long may their highness thrive. silence his mouth with rupee keep their circle intact. 
appoint a colonel from chatham who manage the bhamo state line. the which be one mile and one furlong a guarantee twenty inch gauge. so exeter battleby tring consent his claim to resign and die on four thousand a month in the ninetieth year of his age. 
delilah. 
we have another viceroy now those day be dead and do of delilah aberyswith and deprave ulysses gunne. 
delilah aberyswith be a lady not too young with a perfect taste in dress and a badly bitted tongue with a thirst for information and a great thirst for praise and a little house in simla in the prehistoric day. 
by reason of her marriage to a gentleman in power delilah be acquaint with the gossip of the hour. and many little secret of the half official kind be whisper to delilah and she bore them all in mind. 
she patronize extensively a man ulysses gunne whose mode of earn money be a low and shameful one. he write for certain paper which a everybody know be bad than serve in a shop or scar off the crow. 
he praise her queenly beauty first. and late on he hint at the vastness of her intellect with compliment unstinted. he go with her a rid and his love for her be such that he lend her all his horse and she gall them very much. 
one day they brew a secret of a fine financial sort. it relate to appointment to a man and a report. twas almost worth the keep only seven people know it and gunne rise up to seek the truth and patiently pursue it. 
it be a viceroy s secret but perhaps the wine be red perhaps an age councillor have lose his age head perhaps delilah s eye be bright delilah s whisper sweet the age member tell her what twere treason to repeat. 
ulysses go a rid and they talk of love and flower. ulysses go a call and he call for several hour. ulysses go a waltz and delilah help him dance ulysses let the waltz go and wait for his chance. 
the summer sun be set and the summer air be still the couple go a walk in the shade of summer hill. the wasteful sunset fade out in turkish green and gold ulysses plead softly and that bad delilah tell. 
next morn a startle empire learn the all important news. next week the age councillor be shake in his shoe. next month i meet delilah and she do not show the least hesitation in affirm that ulysses be a beast. * * * * *. 
we have another viceroy now those day be dead and do of delilah aberyswith and most mean ulysses gunne. 
what happen. 
hurree chunder mookerjee pride of bow bazaar owner of a native press barrishter at lar wait on the government with a claim to wear sabre by the bucketful rifle by the pair. 
then the indian government wink a wicked wink say to chunder mookerjee. stick to pen and ink. they be safe implement but if you insist we will let you carry arm wheresoe er you list. 
hurree chunder mookerjee seek the gunsmith and buy the tube of lancaster ballard dean and bland buy a shiny bowie knife buy a town make sword jingle like a carriage horse when he go abroad. 
but the indian government always keen to please also give permission to horrid men like these yar mahommed yusufzai down to kill or steal chimbu singh from bikaneer tantia the bhil. 
killar khan the marri chief jowar singh the sikh nubbee baksh punjabi jat abdul huq rafiq he be a wahabi. last little boh hla oo take advantage of the act take a snide too. 
they be unenlightened men ballard know them not. they procure their sword and gun chiefly on the spot. and the lore of century plus a hundred fight make them slow to disregard one another s right. 
with a unanimity dear to patriot heart all those hairy gentleman out of foreign part say. the good old day be back let u go to war. swagger down the grand trunk road into bow bazaar. 
nubbee baksh punjabi jat find a hide bind flail. chimbu singh from bikaneer oil his tonk jezail. yar mahommed yusufzai spat and grin with glee a he grind the butch knife of the khyberee. 
jowar singh the sikh procure sabre quoit and mace abdul huq wahabi jerk his dagger from it place while amid the jungle grass dance and grin and jabber little boh hla oo and clear his dah blade from the scabbard. 
what become of mookerjee. soothly who can say. yar mahommed only grin in a nasty way jowar singh be reticent chimbu singh be mute. but the belt of all of them simply bulge with loot. 
what become of ballard s gun. afghan black and grubby sell them for their silver weight to the men of pubbi. and the shiny bowie knife and the town make sword be hang in a marri camp just across the border. 
what become of mookerjee. ask mahommed yar prod siva s sacred bull down the bow bazaar. speak to placid nubbee baksh question land and sea ask the indian congressman only don t ask me. 
pink domino. 
they be fool who kiss and tell wisely ha the poet sing. man may hold all sort of post if he ll only hold his tongue. 
jenny and me be engage you see on the eve of the fancy ball. so a kiss or two be nothing to you or any one else at all. 
jenny would go in a domino pretty and pink but warm. while i attend clothe in a splendid austrian uniform. 
now we have arrange through note exchange early that afternoon at number four to waltz no more but to sit in the dusk and spoon. 
i wish you to see that jenny and me have barely exchange our troth. so a kiss or two be strictly due by from and between u both. 
when three be over an eager lover i flee to the gloom outside. and a domino come out also whom i take for my future bride. 
that be to say in a casual way i slip my arm around her. with a kiss or two. which be nothing to you. and ready to kiss i find her. 
she turn her head and the name she say be certainly not my own. but ere i could speak with a smother shriek she flee and leave me alone. 
then jenny come and i saw with shame she d doff her domino. and i have embrace an alien waist but i do not tell her so. 
next morn i know that there be two domino pink and one have cloak the spouse of sir julian house our big political gun. 
sir j. be old and her hair be gold and her eye be a blue cerulean. and the name she say when she turn her head be not in the least like julian. 
the man who could write. 
shun shun the bowl. that fatal facile drink ha ruin many goose who dip their quill in t. bribe murder marry but steer clear of ink save when you write receipt for pay up bill in t. 
there may be silver in the blue black all i know of be the iron and the gall. 
boanerges blitzen servant of the queen be a dismal failure be a might have be. in a luckless moment he discover men rise to high position through a ready pen. boanerges blitzen argue therefore i with the selfsame weapon can attain a high. only he do not posse when he make the trial wicked wit of c lv n irony of l l. 
[men who spar with government need to back their blow something more than ordinary journalistic prose. ]. 
never young civilian s prospect be so bright till an indian paper find that he could write. never young civilian s prospect be so dark when the wretched blitzen write to make his mark. certainly he score it bold and black and firm in that indian paper make his senior squirm quote office scandal write the tactless truth be there ever know a more misguide youth. when the rag he write for praise his plucky game boanerges blitzen felt that this be fame. when the men he write of shake their head and swear boanerges blitzen only write the more. 
pose a young ithuriel resolute and grim till he find promotion didn t come to him. till he find that reprimand weekly be his lot and his many district curiously hot. 
till he find his furlough strangely hard to win boanerges blitzen didn t care to pin. then it seem to dawn on him something wasn t right boanerges blitzen put it down to spite. 
languish in a district desolate and dry. watch the local government yearly pas him by. wonder where the hitch be. call it most unfair. * * * * * * * * *. 
that be seven year ago and he still be there. 
municipal. 
why be my district death rate low. say binks of hezabad. well drain and sewage outfall be my own peculiar fad. 
i learn a lesson once it run thus quoth that most veracious man. 
it be an august even and in snowy garment clothe i pay a round of visit in the line of hezabad. when presently my waler saw and do not like at all a commissariat elephant career down the mall. 
i couldn t see the driver and across my mind it rush that that commissariat elephant have suddenly go musth. 
i didn t care to meet him and i couldn t well get down so i let the waler have it and we head for the town. 
the buggy be a new one and praise dyke it stand the strain till the waler jump a bullock just above the city drain. and the next that i remember be a hurricane of squeal and the creature make toothpick of my five foot patent wheel. 
he seem to want the owner so i flee distraught with fear to the main drain sewage outfall while he snort in my ear reach the four foot drain head safely and in darkness and despair felt the brute s proboscis finger my terror stiffen hair. 
hear it trumpet on my shoulder try to crawl a little high find the main drain sewage outfall block some eight foot up with mire. and for twenty reek minute sir my very marrow freeze while the trunk be feel blindly for a purchase on my toe. 
it miss me by a fraction but my hair be turn grey before they call the driver up and drag the brute away. 
then i seek the city elder and my word be very plain. they flush that four foot drain head and it never choke again. 
you may hold with surface drainage and the sun for garbage cure till you ve be a periwinkle shrink coyly up a sewer. 
i believe in well flush culvert. 
this be why the death rate s small. and if you don t believe me get shikarred yourself. that s all. 
a code of moral. 
l you should think this story true i merely mention i evolve it lately. ti a most unmitigated misstatement. 
now jones have leave his new wed bride to keep his house in order and hie away to the hurrum hill above the afghan border to sit on a rock with a heliograph. but ere he leave he teach his wife the work of the code that set the mile at naught. 
and love have make him very sage a nature make her fair. so cupid and apollo link per heliograph the pair. at dawn across the hurrum hill he flash her counsel wise at e en the die sunset bore her husband s homily. 
he warn her gainst seductive youth in scarlet clothe and gold a much a gainst the blandishment paternal of the old. but keep his grave warning for. hereby the ditty hang. that snowy haired lothario lieutenant general bang. 
twas general bang with aide and staff who tittup on the way when they behold a heliograph tempestuously at play. they think of border rising and of station sack and burn so stop to take the message down and this be what they learn. 
dash dot dot dot dot dash dot dash dot twice. the general swear. 
be ever general officer address a dear before. my love i faith. my duck gadzooks. my darling popsy wop. spirit of great lord wolseley who be on that mountaintop. 
the artless aide de camp be mute. the gild staff be still a dumb with pen up mirth they book that message from the hill. for clear a summer lightning flare the husband s warn run. don t dance or ride with general bang a most immoral man. 
[at dawn across the hurrum hill he flash her counsel wise but howsoever love be blind the world at large hath eye. ] with damnatory dot and dash he heliograph his wife some interest detail of the general s private life. 
the artless aide de camp be mute the shin staff be still and red and ever red grow the general s shave gill. 
and this be what he say at last. his feeling matter not. i think we ve tap a private line. hi. three about there. trot. 
all honour unto bang for ne er do jones thereafter know by word or act official who read off that helio. 
but the tale be on the frontier and from michni to mooltan they know the worthy general a that most immoral man. 
the last department. 
twelve hundred million men be spread about this earth and i and you wonder when you and i be dead what will those luckless million do. 
none whole or clean we cry or free from stain of favour. wait awhile till we attain the last department where nor fraud nor fool nor grade nor greed shall trouble u again. 
fear favour or affection what be these to the grim head who claim our service. i never know a wife or interest yet delay that pukka step miscall decease. 
when leave long overdue none can deny. when idleness of all eternity become our furlough and the marigold our thriftless bullion mint treasury. 
transfer to the eternal settlement each in his strait wood scantled office pen no long brown revers smith s appeal or jones record his minute of dissent. 
and one long since a pillar of the court a mud between the beam thereof be work. and one who write on phosphate for the crop be subject matter of his own report. 
these be the glorious end whereto we pas let him who be go call on him who be. and he shall see the mallie steal the slab for currie grinder and for goat the grass. 
a breath of wind a border bullet s flight a draught of water or a horse s fright the drone of the fat sheristadar cease the punkah stop and fall the night. 
for you or me. do those who live decline the step that offer or their work resign. trust me today s most indispensables five hundred men can take your place or mine.

lord god of host be with u yet l we forget l we forget. 
the tumult and the shout dy the captain and the king depart still stand thine ancient sacrifice an humble and a contrite heart. 
lord god of host be with u yet l we forget l we forget. 
far call our navy melt away on dune and headland sink the fire lo all our pomp of yesterday be one with nineveh and tyre. 
judge of the nation spare u yet l we forget l we forget. 
if drink with sight of power we loose wild tongue that have not thee in awe such boasting a the gentile use or less breed without the law. 
lord god of host be with u yet l we forget l we forget. 
for heathen heart that put her trust in reek tube and iron shard all valiant dust that build on dust and guard call not thee to guard. 
for frantic boast and foolish word thy mercy on thy people lord. amen. 
the vampire. 
the verse a suggest by the paint by philip burne jones first exhibit at the new gallery in london in. 
a fool there be and he make his prayer. even a you and i. to a rag and a bone and a hank of hair. we call her the woman who do not care. but the fool he call her his lady fair. even a you and i. 
oh the year we waste and the tear we waste and the work of our head and hand belong to the woman who do not know. and now we know that she never could know. and do not understand. 
a fool there be and his good he spend. even a you and i. honor and faith and a sure intent but a fool must follow his natural bend. and it wasn t the least what the lady mean. even a you and i. 
oh the toil we lose and the spoil we lose and the excellent thing we plan belong to the woman who didn t know why. and now we know she never know why. and do not understand. 
the fool we strip to his foolish hide. even a you and i. which she might have see when she throw him aside. but it isn t on record the lady try. so some of him live but the most of him die. even a you and i. 
and it isn t the shame and it isn t the blame that sting like a white hot brand. 
it s come to know that she never know why. see at last she could never know why. and never could understand. 
to the unknown goddess. 
will you conquer my heart with your beauty. my soul go out from afar. shall i fall to your hand a a victim of crafty and cautious shikar. 
have i meet you and pass you already unknowing unthinking and blind. shall i meet you next session at simla o sweet and best of your kind. 
doe the p. and o. bear you to meward or clothe in short frock in the west be you grow the charm that shall capture and torture the heart in my breast. 
will you stay in the plain till september my passion a warm a the day. will you bring me to book on the mountain or where the thermantidotes play. 
when the light of your eye shall make pallid the mean less light i pursue and the charm of your presence shall lure me from love of the gay thirteen two. 
when the peg and the pig skin shall please not. when i buy me calcutta build clothe. when i quit the delight of wild ass. forswear the swear of oath. a a deer to the hand of the hunter when i turn mid the gibe of my friend. when the day of my freedom be number and the life of the bachelor end. 
ah goddess. child spinster or widow a of old on mar hill whey they raise to the god that they know not an altar so i a young pagan have praise the goddess i know not nor worship. yet if half that men tell me be true you will come in the future and therefore these verse be write to you. 
the rupaiyat of omar kal vin. 
[allowing for the difference twixt prose and rhyme exaggeration this ought to reproduce the sense of what sir a tell the nation sometime ago when the government strike from our income two per cent. ]. 
now the new year revive last year s debt the thoughtful fisher casteth wide his net. so i with beg dish and ready tongue assail all men for all that i can get. 
import indeed be go with all their due lo. salt a lever that i dare not use nor may i ask the tiller in bengal surely my kith and kin will not refuse. 
pay and i promise by the dust of spring retrenchment. if my promise can bring comfort ye have them now a thousandfold by allah. i will promise anything. 
indeed indeed retrenchment oft before i swear but do i mean it when i swear. and then and then we wander to the hill and so the little le become much more. 
whether a boileaugunge or babylon i know not how the wretched thing be do the item of receipt grow surely small. the item of expense mount one by one. 
i cannot help it. what have i to do with one and five or four or three or two. let scribe spit blood and sulphur a they please or statesman call me foolish heed not you. 
behold i promise anything you will. behold i greet you with an empty till ah. fellow sinner of your charity seek not the reason of the dearth but fill. 
for if i sin and fell where lie the gain of knowledge. would it ease you of your pain to know the tangle thread of revenue i ravel deep in a hopeless skein. 
who hath not prudence what be it i say of her who paint her eye and tire her head and gibe and mock the people in the street and fawn upon them for her thriftless bread.

my rival.

she ride with half a dozen men. she call them boy and masher. i trot along the mall alone. my pretty frock and sash don t help to fill my programme card and vainly i repine from ten to two a. m. ah me. would i be forty nine.

so long a down the rock floor the rave polka spin so long a kitchen lancer spur the madden violin so long a through the whirl smoke we hear the oft tell tale twelve hundred in the lottery and whatshername for sale. if you love me a i love you we ll play the game and win it too. 
so long a lust or lucre tempt straight rider from the course so long a with each drink we pour black brewage of remorse so long a those unload gun we keep beside the bed blow off by obvious accident the lucky owner s head if you love me a i love you what can life kill or death undo. 
so long a death twixt dance and dance chill best and brave blood and drop the reckless rider down the rotten rain soak khud so long a rumour from the north make love wife afraid so long a burma take the boy or typhoid kill the maid if you love me a i love you what knife can cut our love in two. 
by all that light our daily life or work our lifelong woe from boileaugunge to simla down and those grim glade below where heedless of the fly hoof and clamour overhead sleep with the grey langur for guard our very scornful dead if you love me a i love you all earth be servant to u two. 
by docket billetdoux and file by mountain cliff and fir by fan and sword and office box by corset plume and spur by riot revel waltz and war by woman work and bill by all the life that fizz in the everlasting hill if you love me a i love you what pair so happy a we two. 
certain maxim of hafiz. 
i. if it be pleasant to look on stall in the pack serai doe not the young man try it temper and pace ere he buy. if she be pleasant to look on what doe the young man say. lo. she be pleasant to look on give her to me today. 
ii. yea though a kafir die to him be remit jehannum if he borrow in life from a native at sixty per cent. per annum. 
iii. blister we not for bursati. so when the heart be vex the pain of one maiden s refusal be drown in the pain of the next. 
iv. the temper of chum the love of your wife and a new piano s tune which of the three will you trust at the end of an indian june. 
v. who be the ruler of ind to whom shall we bow the knee. make your peace with the woman and men will make you l. g. 
vi. doe the woodpecker flit round the young ferash. doe grass clothe a new build wall. be she under thirty the woman who hold a boy in her thrall. 
vii. if she grow suddenly gracious reflect. be it all for thee. the black buck be stalk through the bullock and man through jealousy. 
viii. seek not for favor of woman. so shall you find it indeed. doe not the boar break cover just when you re light a weed. 
ix. if he play be young and unskilful for shekel of silver and gold take his money my son praise allah. the kid be ordain to be sell. 
x. with a weed among men or horse verily this be the best that you work him in office or dog cart lightly but give him no rest. 
xi. pleasant the snaffle of courtship improve the manner and carriage. but the colt who be wise will abstain from the terrible thorn bite of marriage. 
xii. a the thriftless gold of the babul so be the gold that we spend on a derby sweep or our neighbor s wife or the horse that we buy from a friend. 
xiii. the way of man with a maid be strange yet simple and tame to the way of a man with a horse when sell or race that same. 
xiv. in public her face turneth to thee and pleasant her smile when ye meet. it be ill. the cold rock of el gidar smile thus on the wave at their foot. 
in public her face be avert with anger. she nameth thy name. it be well. be there ever a loser content with the loss of the game. 
xv. if she have speak a word remember thy lip be seal and the brand of the dog be upon him by whom be the secret reveal. 
if she have write a letter delay not an instant but burn it. tear it to piece o fool and the wind to her mate shall return it. 
if there be trouble to herward and a lie of the black can clear lie while thy lip can move or a man be alive to hear. xvi. my son if a maiden deny thee and scufflingly bid thee give o er yet lip meet with lip at the last word get out. she ha be there before. they be peck on the ear and the chin and the nose who be lack in lore. 
xvii. if we fall in the race though we win the hoof slide be scar on the course. though allah and earth pardon sin remaineth forever remorse. 
xviii. by all i be misunderstand. if the matron shall say or the maid. ala. i do not understand my son be thou nowise afraid. 
in vain in the sight of the bird be the net of the fowler display. 
xix. my son if i hafiz the father take hold of thy knee in my pain demand thy name on stamp paper one day or one hour refrain. 
be the link of thy fetter so light that thou cravest another man s chain. 
the grave of the hundred head. 
there s a widow in sleepy chester who weep for her only son. there s a grave on the pabeng river a grave that the burmans shun and there s subadar prag tewarri who tell how the work be do. 
a snide squibbed in the jungle somebody laugh and flee and the men of the first shikaris pick up their subaltern dead with a big blue mark in his forehead and the back blow out of his head. 
subadar prag tewarri jemadar hira lal take command of the party twenty rifle in all march them down to the river a the day be begin to fall. 
they bury the boy by the river a blanket over his face they weep for their dead lieutenant the men of an alien race they make a samadh in his honor a mark for his rest place. 
for they swear by the holy water they swear by the salt they eat that the soul of lieutenant eshmitt sahib should go to his god in state. with fifty file of burman to open him heaven s gate. 
the men of the first shikaris march till the break of day till they come to the rebel village the village of pabengmay a jingal cover the clear calthrops hamper the way. 
subadar prag tewarri bid them load with ball halt a dozen rifle under the village wall. send out a flank party with jemadar hira lal. 
the men of the first shikaris shout and smite and slew turn the grin jingal on to the howl crew. the jemadar s flank party butcher the folk who fly. 
long be the morn of slaughter long be the list of slay five score head be take five score head and twain. and the men of the first shikaris go back to their grave again. 
each man bear a basket red a his palm that day red a the blaze village the village of pabengmay and the drip drip drip from the basket redden the grass by the way. 
they make a pile of their trophy high a a tall man s chin head upon head distort set in a sightless grin anger and pain and terror stamp on the smoke scorch skin. 
subadar prag tewarri put the head of the boh on the top of the mound of triumph the head of his son below with the sword and the peacock banner that the world might behold and know. 
thus the samadh be perfect thus be the lesson plain of the wrath of the first shikaris the price of a white man slay. and the men of the first shikaris go back into camp again. 
then a silence come to the river a hush fell over the shore and bohs that be brave depart and sniders squibbed no more. for the burmans say that a kullah s head must be pay for with head five score. 
there s a widow in sleepy chester who weep for her only son. there s a grave on the pabeng river a grave that the burmans shun and there s subadar prag tewarri who tell how the work be do. 
the moon of other day. 
beneath the deep veranda s shade when bat begin to fly i sit me down and watch ala. another even die. 
blood red behind the sere ferash she rise through the haze. saint diana. can that be the moon of other day. 
ah. shade of little kitty smith sweet saint of kensington. say be it ever thus at home the moon of august shine when arm in arm we wander long through putney s even haze and hammersmith be heaven beneath the moon of other day. 
but wandle s stream be sutlej now and putney s even haze the dust that half a hundred kine before my window raise. unkempt unclean athwart the mist the seethe city loom in place of putney s golden gorse the sickly babul bloom. 
glare down old hecate through the dust and bid the pie dog yell draw from the drain it typhoid germ from each bazaar it smell. yea suck the fever from the tank and sap my strength therewith. thank heaven you show a smile face to little kitty smith. 
the overland mail. foot service to the hill. 
in the name of the empress of india make way o lord of the jungle wherever you roam. the wood be astir at the close of the day we exile be wait for letter from home. let the robber retreat let the tiger turn tail in the name of the empress the overland mail. 
with a jingle of bell a the dusk gather in he turn to the foot path that head up the hill the bag on his back and a cloth round his chin and tuck in his waist belt the post office bill. despatch on this date a receive by the rail per runner two bag of the overland mail. 
be the torrent in spate. he must ford it or swim. ha the rain wreck the road. he must climb by the cliff. doe the tempest cry halt. what be tempest to him. the service admit not a but or and if. while the breath s in his mouth he must bear without fail in the name of the empress the overland mail. 
from aloe to rise oak from rise oak to fir from level to upland from upland to crest from rice field to rock ridge from rock ridge to spur fly the soft sandalled foot strain the brawny brown chest. from rail to ravine to the peak from the vale up up through the night go the overland mail. 
there s a speck on the hillside a dot on the road a jingle of bell on the foot path below there s a scuffle above in the monkey s abide the world be awake and the cloud be aglow. 
for the great sun himself must attend to the hail. in the name of the empress the overland mail. 
what the people say june st. 
by the well where the bullock go silent and blind and slow by the field where the young corn dy in the face of the sultry sky they have hear a the dull earth hear the voice of the wind of an hour the sound of the great queen s voice. my god hath give me year hath grant dominion and power. and i bid you o land rejoice. 
and the ploughman settle the share more deep in the grudge clod. for he saith. the wheat be my care and the rest be the will of god. 
he send the mahratta spear a he sendeth the rain and the mlech in the fat year break the spear in twain. 
and be break in turn. who know how our lord make strife. it be good that the young wheat grow for the bread be life. 
then far and near a the twilight draw hiss up to the scornful dark great serpent blaze of red and blue that rise and fade and rise anew. 
that the land might wonder and mark today be a day of day they say make merry o people all. and the ploughman listen and bow his head. today and tomorrow god s will he say a he trim the lamp on the wall. 
he sendeth u year that be good a he sendeth the dearth he giveth to each man his food or her food to the earth. 
our king and our queen be afar on their people be peace god bringeth the rain to the bar that our cattle increase. 
and the ploughman settle the share more deep in the sun dry clod. mogul mahratta and mlech from the north and white queen over the sea god raiseth them up and driveth them forth a the dust of the ploughshare fly in the breeze. but the wheat and the cattle be all my care and the rest be the will of god. 
the undertaker s horse. 
to tschin shu be condemn to death. how can he drink tea with the executioner. japanese proverb. 
the eldest son bestride him and the pretty daughter ride him and i meet him oft o morning on the course. and there kindle in my bosom an emotion chill and gruesome a i canter past the undertaker s horse. 
neither shy he nor be restive but a hideously suggestive trot professional and placid he affect. and the cadence of his hoof beat to my mind this grim reproof beat. mend your pace my friend i m come. who s the next. 
ah. stud breed of ill omen i have watch the strong go men of pith and might and muscle at your heel down the plantain border highway. heaven send it ne er be my way. in a lacquer box and jetty upon wheel. 
answer sombre beast and dreary where be brown the young the cheery smith the pride of all his friend and half the force. you be at that last dread dak we must cover at a walk bring them back to me o undertaker s horse. 
with your mane unhogged and flow and your curious way of go and that businesslike black crimp of your tail e en with beauty on your back sir pace a a lady s hack sir what wonder when i meet you i turn pale. 
it may be you wait your time beast till i write my last bad rhyme beast quit the sunlight cut the rhyme drop the glass follow after with the others where some dusky heathen smother u with marigold in lieu of english grass. 
or perchance in year to follow i shall watch your plump side hollow see carnifex. go lame. become a corse see old age at last o erpower you and the station pack devour you i shall chuckle then o undertaker s horse. 
but to insult jibe and quest i ve still the hideously suggestive trot that hammer out the unrelenting text and i hear it hard behind me in what place soe er i find me. sure to catch you sooner or late. who s the next. 
the fall of jock gillespie. 
this fell when dinner time be do twixt the first an the second rub that oor mon jock cam hame again to his room ahist the club. 
an syne he laugh an syne he sing an syne we thocht him fou an syne he trump his partner s trick an garred his partner rue. 
then up and spake an elder mon that hold the spade it ace god save the lad. whence come the licht that wimple on his face. 
an jock he snigger an jock he smile an ower the card brim wunk. i m a too fresh fra the stirrup peg may be that i be drink. 
there s whusky brew in galashils an l. l. l. forbye. but never liquor light the lowe that keeks fra oot your eye. 
there s a third o hair on your dress coat breast aboon the heart a wee. oh. that be fra the lang haired skye that slobber ower me. 
oh. lang haired sky be lovin beast an terrier dog be fair but never yet be terrier bear wi ell lang gowden hair. 
there s a smirch o pouther on your breast below the leave lappel. oh. that be fra my auld cigar whenas the stump end fell. 
mon jock ye smoke the trichi coarse for ye be short o cash an best havana couldna leave sae white an pure an ash. 
this nicht ye stop a story braid an stop it wi a curse. last nicht ye tell that tale yoursel an cap it wi a bad. 
oh. we re no fou. oh. we re no fou. but plainly we can ken ye re fallin fallin fra the band o cantie single men. 
an it fell when sirris shaw be sere an the nichts be lang and mirk in braw new breeks wi a gowden ring oor jock gaed to the kirk. 
arithmetic on the frontier. 
a great and glorious thing it be to learn for seven year or so the lord know what of that and this ere reckon fit to face the foe the fly bullet down the pas that whistle clear. all flesh be grass. 
three hundred pound per annum spend on make brain and body meeter for all the murderous intent comprise in villainous saltpetre. and after ask the yusufzaies what come of all our ology. 
a scrimmage in a border station a canter down some dark defile two thousand pound of education drop to a ten rupee jezail the crammer s boast the squadron s pride shoot like a rabbit in a ride. 
no proposition euclid write no formula the text book know will turn the bullet from your coat or ward the tulwar s downward blow strike hard who care shoot straight who can the odds be on the cheap man. 
one sword knot steal from the camp will pay for all the school expense of any kurrum valley scamp who know no word of mood and tense but be bless with perfect sight pick off our messmate leave and right. 
with home breed horde the hillside teem the troop ship bring u one by one at vast expense of time and steam to slay afridis where they run. 
the captive of our bow and spear be cheap ala. a we be dear. 
the betroth. 
you must choose between me and your cigar. breach of promise case circa. 
open the old cigar box get me a cuba stout for thing be run crossway and maggie and i be out. 
we quarrel about havana we fight o er a good cheroot and i know she be exact and she say i be a brute. 
open the old cigar box let me consider a space. in the soft blue veil of the vapour muse on maggie s face. 
maggie be pretty to look at maggie s a love lass but the pretty cheek must wrinkle the true of love must pas. 
there s peace in a larranaga there s calm in a henry clay. but the best cigar in an hour be finish and throw away. 
throw away for another a perfect and ripe and brown but i could not throw away maggie for fear o the talk o the town. 
maggie my wife at fifty grey and dour and old with never another maggie to purchase for love or gold. 
and the light of day that have be the dark of the day that be and love s torch stink and stale like the butt of a dead cigar. 
the butt of a dead cigar you be bind to keep in your pocket with never a new one to light tho it s char and black to the socket. 
open the old cigar box let me consider a while. here be a mild manila there be a wifely smile. 
which be the good portion bondage buy with a ring or a harem of dusky beauty fifty tie in a string. 
counsellor cunning and silent comforter true and try and never a one of the fifty to sneer at a rival bride. 
think in the early morning solace in time of woe peace in the hush of the twilight balm ere my eyelid close. 
this will the fifty give me ask nought in return with only a suttee s passion to do their duty and burn. 
this will the fifty give me. when they be spend and dead five time other fifty shall be my servant instead. 
the furrow of far off java the isle of the spanish main when they hear my harem be empty will send me my bride again. 
i will take no heed to their raiment nor food for their mouth withal so long a the gull be nest so long a the shower fall. 
i will scent em with best vanilla with tea will i temper their hide and the moor and the mormon shall envy who read of the tale of my bride. 
for maggie ha write a letter to give me my choice between the wee little whimper love and the great god nick o teen. 
and i have be servant of love for barely a twelvemonth clear but i have be priest of cabana a matter of seven year. 
and the gloom of my bachelor day be fleck with the cheery light of stump that i burn to friendship and pleasure and work and fight. 
and i turn my eye to the future that maggie and i must prove but the only light on the marsh be the will o the wisp of love. 
will it see me safe through my journey or leave me bogged in the mire. since a puff of tobacco can cloud it shall i follow the fitful fire. 
open the old cigar box let me consider anew old friend and who be maggie that i should abandon you. 
a million surplus maggies be will to bear the yoke. and a woman be only a woman but a good cigar be a smoke. 
light me another cuba i hold to my first swear vow. if maggie will have no rival i ll have no maggie for spouse. 
a tale of two city. 
where the sober color cultivator smile on his byles. where the cholera the cyclone and the crow come and go. where the merchant deal in indigo and tea hide and ghi. where the babu drop inflammatory hint in his print. stand a city charnock choose it pack away near a bay by the sewage render fetid by the sewer make impure by the sunderbunds unwholesome by the swamp moist and damp. and the city and the viceroy a we see don t agree. 
once two hundred year ago the trader come meek and tame. 
where his timid foot first halt there he stay till mere trade grow to empire and he send his army forth south and north till the country from peshawur to ceylon be his own. 
thus the midday halt of charnock more s the pity. grow a city. 
a the fungus sprout chaotic from it bed so it spread chance direct chance erect lay and build on the silt palace byre hovel poverty and pride side by side. and above the pack and pestilential town death look down. 
but the ruler in that city by the sea turn to flee flee with each return spring tide from it ill to the hill. 
from the clammy fog of morning from the blaze of old day from the sickness of the noontide from the heat beat retreat. for the country from peshawur to ceylon be their own. 
but the merchant risk the peril of the plain for his gain. 
now the rest place of charnock neath the palm ask an alms and the burden of it lamentation be briefly this. because for certain month we boil and stew so should you. 
cast the viceroy and his council to perspire in our fire. and for answer to the argument in vain we explain that an amateur saint lawrence cannot fry. all must fry. that the merchant risk the peril of the plain for gain. 
nor can ruler rule a house that men grow rich in from it kitchen. 
let the babu drop inflammatory hint in his print. and mature consistent soul his plan for steal to darjeeling. let the merchant seek who make his silver pile england s isle. let the city charnock pitch on evil day. go her way. 
though the argosy of asia at her door heap their store though her enterprise and energy secure income sure though out station order punctually obey swell her trade still for rule administration and the rest simla s best. 
the end * * * * * * * *. 
volume ii ballad and barrack room ballad. 
ballad. 
the ballad of east and west. 
oh east be east and west be west and never the twain shall meet till earth and sky stand presently at god s great judgment seat. but there be neither east nor west border nor breed nor birth when two strong men stand face to face tho they come from the end of the earth. 
kamal be out with twenty men to raise the border side and he ha lift the colonel s mare that be the colonel s pride. he ha lift her out of the stable door between the dawn and the day and turn the calkin upon her foot and ride her far away. 
then up and speak the colonel s son that lead a troop of the guide. be there never a man of all my men can say where kamal hide. then up and speak mahommed khan the son of the ressaldar. if ye know the track of the morning mist ye know where his picket be. 
at dusk he harry the abazai at dawn he be into bonair but he must go by fort bukloh to his own place to fare so if ye gallop to fort bukloh a fast a a bird can fly by the favour of god ye may cut him off ere he win to the tongue of jagai. 
but if he be past the tongue of jagai right swiftly turn ye then for the length and the breadth of that grisly plain be sow with kamal s men. there be rock to the leave and rock to the right and low lean thorn between and ye may hear a breech bolt snick where never a man be see. 
the colonel s son ha take a horse and a raw rough dun be he with the mouth of a bell and the heart of hell and the head of the gallows tree. 
the colonel s son to the fort ha win they bid him stay to eat who ride at the tail of a border thief he sit not long at his meat. 
he s up and away from fort bukloh a fast a he can fly till he be aware of his father s mare in the gut of the tongue of jagai till he be aware of his father s mare with kamal upon her back and when he could spy the white of her eye he make the pistol crack. 
he ha fire once he ha fire twice but the whistle ball go wide. ye shoot like a soldier kamal say. show now if ye can ride. 
it s up and over the tongue of jagai a blow dustdevils go the dun he flee like a stag of ten but the mare like a barren doe. 
the dun he lean against the bite and slug his head above but the red mare play with the snaffle bar a a maiden play with a glove. 
there be rock to the leave and rock to the right and low lean thorn between and thrice he hear a breech bolt snick tho never a man be see. 
they have ride the low moon out of the sky their hoof drum up the dawn the dun he go like a wound bull but the mare like a new rouse fawn. 
the dun he fell at a water course in a woful heap fell he and kamal ha turn the red mare back and pull the rider free. 
he ha knock the pistol out of his hand small room be there to strive twas only by favour of mine quoth he ye ride so long alive. there be not a rock for twenty mile there be not a clump of tree but cover a man of my own men with his rifle cock on his knee. 
if i have raise my bridle hand a i have hold it low the little jackal that flee so fast be feast all in a row. if i have bow my head on my breast a i have hold it high the kite that whistle above u now be gorge till she could not fly. lightly answer the colonel s son. do good to bird and beast but count who come for the break meat before thou makest a feast. 
if there should follow a thousand sword to carry my bone away belike the price of a jackal s meal be more than a thief could pay. 
they will fee their horse on the stand crop their men on the garner grain the thatch of the byre will serve their fire when all the cattle be slay. 
but if thou thinkest the price be fair thy brother wait to sup the hound be kin to the jackal spawn howl dog and call them up. and if thou thinkest the price be high in steer and gear and stack give me my father s mare again and i ll fight my own way back. 
kamal ha grip him by the hand and set him upon his foot. no talk shall be of dog say he when wolf and gray wolf meet. 
may i eat dirt if thou hast hurt of me in deed or breath. what dam of lance bring thee forth to jest at the dawn with death. lightly answer the colonel s son. i hold by the blood of my clan. take up the mare for my father s gift by god she ha carry a man. the red mare run to the colonel s son and nuzzle against his breast. we be two strong men say kamal then but she loveth the young best. 
so she shall go with a lifter s dower my turquoise stud rein my broider saddle and saddle cloth and silver stirrup twain. the colonel s son a pistol draw and hold it muzzle end ye have take the one from a foe say he. will ye take the mate from a friend. a gift for a gift say kamal straight. a limb for the risk of a limb. 
thy father ha send his son to me i ll send my son to him. with that he whistle his only son that drop from a mountain crest he tread the ling like a buck in spring and he look like a lance in rest. 
now here be thy master kamal say who lead a troop of the guide and thou must ride at his leave side a shield on shoulder ride. till death or i cut loose the tie at camp and board and bed thy life be his thy fate it be to guard him with thy head. 
so thou must eat the white queen s meat and all her foe be thine and thou must harry thy father s hold for the peace of the border line and thou must make a trooper tough and hack thy way to power belike they will raise thee to ressaldar when i be hang in peshawur. 
they have look each other between the eye and there they find no fault they have take the oath of the brother in blood on leaven bread and salt. they have take the oath of the brother in blood on fire and fresh cut sod on the hilt and the haft of the khyber knife and the wondrous name of god. 
the colonel s son he ride the mare and kamal s boy the dun and two have come back to fort bukloh where there go forth but one. 
and when they draw to the quarter guard full twenty sword fly clear there be not a man but carry his feud with the blood of the mountaineer. 
ha do. ha do. say the colonel s son. put up the steel at your side. last night ye have strike at a border thief tonight ti a man of the guide. 
oh east be east and west be west and never the twain shall meet till earth and sky stand presently at god s great judgment seat. but there be neither east nor west border nor breed nor birth when two strong men stand face to face tho they come from the end of the earth. 
the last suttee. 
not many year ago a king die in one of the rajpoot state. his wife disregard the order of the english against suttee would have break out of the palace have not the gate be bar. 
but one of them disguise a the king s favourite dance girl pass through the line of guard and reach the pyre. there her courage fail she pray her cousin a baron of the court to kill her. this he do not know who she be. 
udai chand lay sick to death in his hold by gungra hill. all night we hear the death gong ring for the soul of the die rajpoot king all night beat up from the woman s wing a cry that we could not still. 
all night the baron come and go the lord of the out guard. all night the cressets glimmer pale on ulwar sabre and tonk jezail mewar headstall and marwar mail that clink in the palace yard. 
in the golden room on the palace roof all night he fight for air. and there be sob behind the screen rustle and whisper of woman unseen and the hungry eye of the boondi queen on the death she might not share. 
he pass at dawn the death fire leap from ridge to river head from the malwa plain to the abu scar. and wail upon wail go up to the star behind the grim zenana bar when they know that the king be dead. 
the dumb priest kneel to tie his mouth and robe him for the pyre. the boondi queen beneath u cry. see now that we die a our mother die in the bridal bed by our master s side. out woman. to the fire. 
we drive the great gate home apace. white hand be on the sill. but ere the rush of the unseen foot have reach the turn to the open street the bar shoot down the guard drum beat we hold the dovecot still. 
a face look down in the gather day and laugh speak from the wall. ohe they mourn here. let me by azizun the lucknow nautch girl i. when the house be rotten the rat must fly and i seek another thrall. 
for i rule the king a ne er do queen tonight the queen rule me. guard them safely but let me go or ever they pay the debt they owe in scourge and torture. she leap below and the grim guard watch her flee. 
they know that the king have spend his soul on a north breed dance girl. that he pray to a flat nose lucknow god and kiss the grind where her foot have tread and doom to death at her drunken nod and swear by her light curl. 
we bore the king to his father place where the tomb of the sun bear stand. where the gray ape swing and the peacock preen on fret pillar and jewel screen and the wild boar couch in the house of the queen on the drift of the desert sand. 
the herald read his title forth we set the log aglow. friend of the english free from fear baron of luni to jeysulmeer lord of the desert of bikaneer king of the jungle go. 
all night the red flame stab the sky with waver wind toss spear. and out of a shatter temple creep a woman who veil her head and weep and call on the king but the great king sleep and turn not for her tear. 
small think have he to mark the strife cold fear with hot desire when thrice she leap from the leap flame and thrice she beat her breast for shame and thrice like a wound dive she come and moan about the fire. 
one watch a bow shoot from the blaze the silent street between who have stand by the king in sport and fray to blade in ambush or boar at bay and he be a baron old and gray and kin to the boondi queen. 
he say. o shameless put aside the veil upon thy brow. who hold the king and all his land to the wanton will of a harlot s hand. will the white ash rise from the blister brand. stoop down and call him now. 
then she. by the faith of my tarnish soul all thing i do not well i have hop to clear ere the fire die and lay me down by my master s side to rule in heaven his only bride while the others howl in hell. 
but i have felt the fire s breath and hard it be to die. yet if i may pray a rajpoot lord to sully the steel of a thakur s sword with base bear blood of a trade abhor and the thakur answer ay. 
he draw and strike. the straight blade drink the life beneath the breast. 
i have look for the queen to face the flame but the harlot dy for the rajpoot dame sister of mine pas free from shame pas with thy king to rest. 
the black log crash above the white. the little flame and lean red a slaughter and blue a steel that whistle and flutter from head to heel leap up anew for they find their meal on the heart of the boondi queen. 
the ballad of the king s mercy. 
abdhur rahman the durani chief of him be the story tell. his mercy fill the khyber hill his grace be manifold. he ha take toll of the north and the south his glory reacheth far and they tell the tale of his charity from balkh to kandahar. 
before the old peshawur gate where kurd and kaffir meet the governor of kabul deal the justice of the street and that be strait a run noose and swift a plunge knife tho he who hold the long purse might hold the long life. 
there be a hound of hindustan have strike a euzufzai wherefore they spat upon his face and lead him out to die. 
it chance the king go forth that hour when throat be bar to knife. the kaffir grovel under hoof and clamour for his life. 
then say the king. have hope o friend. yea death disgrace be hard. much honour shall be thine. and call the captain of the guard yar khan a bastard of the blood so city babble saith and he be honour of the king the which be salt to death. and he be son of daoud shah the reiver of the plain and blood of old durani lord run fire in his vein. and twas to tame an afghan pride nor hell nor heaven could bind the king would make him butch to a yelp cur of hind. 
strike. say the king. king s blood art thou his death shall be his pride. then loud that the crowd might catch. fear not his arm be tie. yar khan draw clear the khyber knife and strike and sheathe again. o man thy will be do quoth he. a king this dog hath slay. 
abdhur rahman the durani chief to the north and the south be sell. the north and the south shall open their mouth to a ghilzai flag unroll when the big gun speak to the khyber peak and his dog heratis fly. ye have hear the song how long. how long. wolf of the abazai.

and grimly say the afghan king. i rule the afghan race. my path be mine see thou to thine tonight upon thy bed think who there be in kabul now that clamour for thy head. 
that night when all the gate be shut to city and to throne within a little garden house the king lay down alone. 
before the sink of the moon which be the night of night yar khan come softly to the king to make his honour white. the child of the town have mock beneath his horse s hoof the harlot of the town have hail him butch. from their roof. 
but a he grope against the wall two hand upon him fell the king behind his shoulder spake. dead man thou dost not well. ti ill to jest with king by day and seek a boon by night. and that thou bearest in thy hand be all too sharp to write. 
but three day hence if god be good and if thy strength remain thou shalt demand one boon of me and bless me in thy pain. for i be merciful to all and most of all to thee. 
my butch of the shamble rest no knife hast thou for me. 
abdhur rahman the durani chief hold hard by the south and the north. but the ghilzai know ere the melt snow when the swell bank break forth when the red coat crawl to the sungar wall and his usbeg lance fail. ye have hear the song how long. how long. wolf of the zuka kheyl. 
they stone him in the rubbish field when dawn be in the sky accord to the write word see that he do not die. 
they stone him till the stone be pile above him on the plain and those the labour limb displace they tumble back again. 
one watch beside the dreary mound that veil the batter thing and him the king with laughter call the herald of the king. 
it be upon the second night the night of ramazan the watcher lean earthward hear the message of yar khan. 
from shatter breast through shrivel lip break forth the rattle breath creature of god deliver me from agony of death. 
they seek the king among his girl and risk their life thereby. protector of the pitiful give order that he die. 
bid him endure until the day a lag answer come. the night be short and he can pray and learn to bless my name. 
before the dawn three time he speak and on the day once more. creature of god deliver me and bless the king therefor. 
they shoot him at the morning prayer to ease him of his pain and when he hear the matchlock clink he bless the king again. 
which thing the singer make a song for all the world to sing so that the out sea may know the mercy of the king.

the ballad of the king s jest. 
when spring time flush the desert grass our kafilas wind through the khyber pas. 
lean be the camel but fat the frail light be the purse but heavy the bale a the snowbound trade of the north come down to the market square of peshawur town. 
in a turquoise twilight crisp and chill a kafila camp at the foot of the hill. 
then blue smoke haze of the cook rise and tent peg answer to hammer nose. and the picket pony shag and wild strain at their rope a the fee be pile. and the bubble camel beside the load sprawl for a furlong adown the road. and the persian pussy cat bring for sale spat at the dog from the camel bale. and the tribesman bellow to hasten the food. and the camp fire twinkle by fort jumrood. and there flee on the wing of the gather dusk a savour of camel and carpet and musk a murmur of voice a reek of smoke to tell u the trade of the khyber wake. 
the lid of the flesh pot chatter high the knife be whet and then come i to mahbub ali the muleteer patch his bridle and count his gear cram with the gossip of half a year. 
but mahbub ali the kindly say good be speech when the belly be feed. so we plunge the hand to the mid wrist deep in a cinnamon stew of the fat tail sheep and he who never hath taste the food by allah. he knoweth not bad from good. 
we cleanse our beard of the mutton grease we lay on the mat and be fill with peace and the talk slide north and the talk slide south with the slide puff from the hookah mouth. 
four thing great than all thing be woman and horse and power and war. 
we spake of them all but the last the most for i seek a word of a russian post of a shifty promise an unsheathe sword and a gray coat guard on the helmund ford. 
then mahbub ali lower his eye in the fashion of one who be weave lie. 
quoth he. of the russian who can say. when the night be gather all be gray. but we look that the gloom of the night shall die in the morning flush of a blood red sky. 
friend of my heart be it meet or wise to warn a king of his enemy. we know what heaven or hell may bring but no man knoweth the mind of the king. 
that unsought counsel be curse of god attesteth the story of wali dad. 
his sire be leaky of tongue and pen his dam be a cluck khuttuck hen. and the colt breed close to the vice of each for he carry the curse of an unstanched speech. 
therewith madness so that he seek the favour of king at the kabul court. and travel in hope of honour far to the line where the gray coat squadron be. 
there have i journey too but i saw naught say naught and do not die. he hark to rumour and snatch at a breath of this one knoweth and that one saith legend that run from mouth to mouth of a gray coat come and sack of the south. 
these have i also hear they pas with each new spring and the winter grass. 
hot foot southward forget of god back to the city run wali dad even to kabul in full durbar the king hold talk with his chief in war. 
into the press of the crowd he break and what he have hear of the come speak. 
then gholam hyder the red chief smile a a mother might on a babble child. but those who would laugh restrain their breath when the face of the king show dark a death. 
evil it be in full durbar to cry to a ruler of gather war. slowly he lead to a peach tree small that grow by a cleave of the city wall. 
and he say to the boy. they shall praise thy zeal so long a the red spurt follow the steel. 
and the rus be upon u even now. great be thy prudence await them thou. watch from the tree. thou art young and strong surely thy vigil be not for long. 
the rus be upon u thy clamour run. surely an hour shall bring their van. wait and watch. when the host be near shout aloud that my men may hear. 
friend of my heart be it meet or wise to warn a king of his enemy. a guard be set that he might not flee a score of bayonet ring the tree. 
the peach bloom fell in shower of snow when he shake at his death a he look below. by the power of god who alone be great till the seventh day he fight with his fate. 
then madness take him and men declare he mow in the branch a ape and bear and last a a sloth ere his body fail and he hang a a bat in the fork and wail and sleep the cord of his hand untie and he fell and be catch on the point and die. 
heart of my heart be it meet or wise to warn a king of his enemy. we know what heaven or hell may bring but no man knoweth the mind of the king. 
of the gray coat come who can say. when the night be gather all be gray. 
to thing great than all thing be the first be love and the second war. 
and since we know not how war may prove heart of my heart let u talk of love. 
the ballad of boh da thone. 
this be the ballad of boh da thone erst a pretender to theebaw s throne who harry the district of alalone. how he meet with his fate and the v. p. p. 
at the hand of harendra mukerji senior gomashta g. b. t. 
boh da thone be a warrior bold. his sword and his snide be boss with gold. 
and the peacock banner his henchman bore be stiff with bullion but stiff with gore. 
he shoot at the strong and he slash at the weak from the salween scrub to the chindwin teak. 
he crucify noble he sacrifice mean he fill old lady with kerosene. 
while over the water the paper cry the patriot fight for his countryside. 
but little they care for the native press the wear white soldier in khaki dress. 
who tramp through the jungle and camp in the byre who die in the swamp and be tombed in the mire. 
who give up their life at the queen s command for the pride of their race and the peace of the land. 
now first of the foeman of boh da thone be captain o neil of the black tyrone and his be a company seventy strong who hustle that dissolute chief along. 
there be lad from galway and louth and meath who go to their death with a joke in their teeth and worship with fluency fervour and zeal the mud on the boot heel of crook o neil. 
but ever a blight on their labour lay and ever their quarry would vanish away till the sun dry boy of the black tyrone take a brotherly interest in boh da thone. and sooth if pursuit in possession end the boh and his tracker be best of friend. 
the word of a scout a march by night a rush through the mist a scatter fight a volley from cover a corpse in the clear the glimpse of a loin cloth and heavy jade earring the flare of a village the tally of slay and. the boh be abroad on the raid again. 
they curse their luck a the irish will they give him credit for cunning and skill they bury their dead they bolt their beef and start anew on the track of the thief till in place of the kalends of greece men say when crook and his darling come back with the head. 
they have hunt the boh from the hill to the plain he double and break for the hill again. they have cripple his power for rapine and raid they have rout him out of his pet stockade and at last they come when the day star tire to a camp desert a village fire. 
a black cross blister the morning gold and the body upon it be stark and cold. the wind of the dawn go merrily past the high grass bow her plume to the blast. 
and out of the grass on a sudden break a spirtle of fire a whorl of smoke. 
and captain o neil of the black tyrone be bless with a slug in the ulnar bone the gift of his enemy boh da thone. 
now a slug that be hammer from telegraph wire be a thorn in the flesh and a rankle fire. * * * * *. 
the shoot wind fester a shoot wound may in a steam barrack at mandalay. 
the leave arm throb and the captain swear i d like to be after the boh once more. the fever hold him the captain say i d give a hundred to look at his head. 
the hospital punkah creak and whir but babu harendra. gomashta. hear. 
he think of the cane brake green and dank that girdle his home by the dacca tank. he think of his wife and his high school son he think but abandon the think of a gun. his sleep be break by vision dread of a shin boh with a silver head. 
he keep his counsel and go his way and swindle the cartmen of half their pay. * * * * *. 
and the month go on a the bad must do and the boh return to the raid anew. 
but the captain have quit the long draw strife and in far simoorie have take a wife. and she be a damsel of delicate mould with hair like the sunshine and heart of gold. 
and little she know the arm that embrace have cleave a man from the brow to the waist. and little she know that the love lip have order a quiver life s eclipse. 
and the eye that light at her light breath have glare unawed in the gate of death. 
for these be matter a man would hide a a general rule from an innocent bride. 
and little the captain think of the past and of all men babu harendra last. * * * * *. 
but slow in the sludge of the kathun road the government bullock train tot it load. speckle and spotless and shin with ghee in the rearmost cart sit the babu jee. 
and ever a phantom before him flee of a scowl boh with a silver head. 
then the lead cart stick though the cooly slave and the cartmen flog and the escort rave. and out of the jungle with yell and squeal prance boh da thone and his gang at his heel. 
then belch blunderbuss answer back the snide s snarl and the carbine s crack and the blithe revolver begin to sing to the blade that twang on the lock ring and the brown flesh blue where the bay net kiss a the steel shoot back with a wrench and a twist and the great white bullock with onyx eye watch the soul of the dead arise and over the smoke of the fusillade the peacock banner stagger and sway. 
oh gay of scrimmage man may see be a well work rush on the g. b. t. 
the babu shake at the horrible sight and gird his ponderous loin for flight but fate have ordain that the boh should start on a lone hand raid of the rearmost cart and out of that cart with a bellow of woe the babu fell flat on the top of the boh. 
for year have harendra serve the state to the growth of his purse and the girth of his pet. 
there be twenty stone a the tally man know on the broad of the chest of this best of bohs. and twenty stone from a height discharge be bad for a boh with a spleen enlarge. 
oh short be the struggle severe be the shock he drop like a bullock he lay like a block. and the babu above him convulse with fear hear the labour life breath hiss out in his ear. 
and thus in a fashion undignified the princely pest of the chindwin die. * * * * *. 
turn now to simoorie where lap in his ease the captain be pet the bride on his knee where the whit of the bullet the wound man s scream be mix a the mist of some devilish dream forget forget the sweat of the shamble where the hill daisy bloom and the gray monkey gambol from the sword belt set free and release from the steel the peace of the lord be with captain o neil. * * * * *. 
up the hill to simoorie most patient of drudge the bag on his shoulder the mail runner trudge. 
for captain o neil sahib. one hundred and ten rupee to collect on delivery. then. 
their breakfast be stop while the screw jack and hammer tear waxcloth split teak wood and chip out the dammer.
