only a subaltern. 
not only to enforce by command but to encourage by example the energetic discharge of duty and the steady endurance of the difficulty and privation inseparable from military service. bengal army regulation. 
they make bobby wick pas an examination at sandhurst. he be a gentleman before he be gazette so when the empress announce that gentleman cadet robert hanna wick be post a second lieutenant to the tyneside tail twister at kram bokhar he become an officer and a gentleman which be an enviable thing. and there be joy in the house of wick where mamma wick and all the little wick fell upon their knee and offer incense to bobby by virtue of his achievement. 
papa wick have be a commissioner in his day hold authority over three million of men in the chota buldana division build great work for the good of the land and do his best to make two blade of grass grow where there be but one before. of course nobody know anything about this in the little english village where he be just old mr. wick and have forget that he be a companion of the order of the star of india. 
he pat bobby on the shoulder and say. well do my boy. 
there follow while the uniform be be prepare an interval of pure delight during which bobby take brevet rank a a man at the women~swamped tennis party and tea fight of the village and i dare say have his join time be extend would have fall in love with several girl at once. little country village at home be very full of nice girl because all the young men come out to india to make their fortune. 
india say papa wick be the place. i ve have thirty year of it and begad i d like to go back again. when you join the tail twister you ll be among friend if every one hasn t forget wick of chota buldana and a lot of people will be kind to you for our sake. the mother will tell you more about outfit than i can but remember this. stick to your regiment bobby stick to your regiment. you ll see men all round you go into the staff corp and do every possible sort of duty but regimental and you may be tempt to follow suit. now so long a you keep within your allowance and i haven t stint you there stick to the line the whole line and nothing but the line. be careful how you back another young fool s bill and if you fall in love with a woman twenty year old than yourself don t tell me about it that s all. 
with these counsel and many others equally valuable do papa wick fortify bobby ere that last awful night at portsmouth when the officer quarter hold more inmate than be provide for by the regulation and the liberty men of the ship fell foul of the draft for india and the battle rag from the dockyard gate even to the slum of longport while the drab of fratton come down and scratch the face of the queen s officer. 
bobby wick with an ugly bruise on his freckle nose a sick and shaky detachment to manoeuvre inship and the comfort of fifty scornful female to attend to have no time to feel homesick till the malabar reach mid channel when he double his emotion with a little guard visit and a great many other matter. 
the tail twister be a most particular regiment. those who know them least say that they be eat up with side. but their reserve and their internal arrangement generally be merely protective diplomacy. some five year before the colonel command have look into the fourteen fearless eye of seven plump and juicy subaltern who have all apply to enter the staff corp and have ask them why the three star should he a colonel of the line command a dash nursery for double dash bottle sucker who put on condemn tin spur and ride qualify moke at the hiatused head of forsake black regiment. he be a rude man and a terrible. wherefore the remnant take measure [with the half butt a an engine of public opinion] till the rumor go abroad that young men who use the tail twister a a crutch to the staff corp have many and vary trial to endure. however. a regiment have just a much right to it own secret a a woman. 
when bobby come up from deolali and take his place among the tail twister it be gently hut firmly bear in upon him that the regiment be his father and his mother and his indissolubly wed wife and that there be no crime under the canopy of heaven black than that of bring shame on the regiment which be the best shoot best drill best set up brave most illustrious and in all respect most desirable regiment within the compass of the seven sea. he be teach the legend of the mess plate from the great grin golden god that have come out of the summer palace in pekin to the silver mount markhor horn snuff mull present by the last c. [he who spake to the seven subalterns]. and every one of those legend tell him of battle fight at long odds without fear a without support. of hospitality catholic a an arab s. of friendship deep a the sea and steady a the fight line. of honor win by hard road for honor s sake. and of instant and unquestioning devotion to the regiment the regiment that claim the life of all and life forever. 
more than once too he come officially into contact with the regimental color which look like the line of a bricklayer s hat on the end of a chew stick. bobby do not kneel and worship them because british subaltern be not construct in that manner. indeed he condemn them for their weight at the very moment that they be fill with awe and other more noble sentiment. 
but best of all be the occasion when he move with the tail twister in review order at the break of a november day. allow for duty men and sick the regiment be one thousand and eighty strong and bobby belong to them. for be he not a subaltern of the line the whole line and nothing but the line a the tramp of two thousand one hundred and sixty sturdy ammunition boot attest. he would not have change place with deighton of the horse battery whirl by in a pillar of cloud to a chorus of strong right. strong leave. or hogan yale of the white hussar lead his squadron for all it be worth with the price of horseshoe throw in. or tick boileau try to live up to his fierce blue and gold turban while the wasp of the bengal cavalry stretch to a gallop in the wake of the long lollopping walers of the white hussar.

in the matter of a private.

people who have see say that one of the quaint spectacle of human frailty be an outbreak of hysteric in a girl school. it start without warn generally on a hot afternoon among the elder pupil. a girl giggle till the giggle get beyond control. then she throw up her head and cry honk honk honk like a wild goose and tear mix with the laughter. if the mistress be wise she will rap out something severe at this point to check matter. if she be tender hearted and send for a drink of water the chance be largely in favor of another girl laugh at the afflict one and herself collapse. thus the trouble spread and may end in half of what answer to the low sixth of a boy school rock and whoop together. give a week of warm weather two stately promenade per diem a heavy mutton and rice meal in the middle of the day a certain amount of nag from the teacher and a few other thing some amaze effect develop. at least this be what folk say who have have experience. 
now the mother superior of a convent and the colonel of a british infantry regiment would be justly shock at any comparison be make between their respective charge. but it be a fact that under certain circumstance thomas in bulk can be work up into dither ripple hysteria. he doe not weep but he show his trouble unmistakably and the consequence get into the newspaper and all the good people who hardly know a martini from a snide say. take away the brute s ammunition. 
thomas isn t a brute and his business which be to look after the virtuous people demand that he shall have his ammunition to his hand. he doesn t wear silk stocking and he really ought to be supply with a new adjective to help him to express his opinion. but for all that he be a great man. if you call him the heroic defender of the national honor one day and a brutal and licentious soldiery the next you naturally bewilder him and he look upon you with suspicion. there be nobody to speak for thomas except people who have theory to work off on him. and nobody understand thomas except thomas and he doe not always know what be the matter with himself. 
that be the prologue. this be the story. 
corporal slane be engage to be marry to miss jhansi m kenna whose history be well know in the regiment and elsewhere. he have his colonel s permission and be popular with the men every arrangement have be make to give the wed what private ortheris call eeklar. it fell in the heart of the hot weather and after the wed slane be go up to the hill with the bride. none the le slane s grievance be that the affair would he only a hire carriage wed and he felt that the eeklar of that be meagre. miss m kenna do not care so much. the sergeant s wife be help her to make her wed dress and she be very busy. slane be just then the only moderately content man in barrack. all the rest be more or le miserable. 
and they have so much to make them happy too. all their work be over at eight in the morning and for the rest of the day they could lie on their back and smoke canteen plug and swear at the punkah cooly. they enjoy a fine full flesh meal in the middle of the day and then throw themselves down on their cot and sweat and sleep till it be cool enough to go out with their towny whose vocabulary contain le than six hundred word and the adjective and whose view on every conceivable question they have hear many time before. 
there be the canteen of course and there be the temperance room with the second hand paper in it. but a man of any profession cannot read for eight hour a day in a temperature of degree or degree in the shade run up sometimes to degree at midnight. very few men even though they get a pannikin of flat stale muddy beer and hide it under their cot can continue drink for six hour a day. one man try but he die and nearly the whole regiment go to his funeral because it give them something to do. it be too early for the excitement of fever or cholera. the men could only wait and wait and wait and watch the shadow of the barrack creep across the blind white dust. that be a gay life. 
they lounge about cantonment it be too hot for any sort of game and almost too hot for vice and fuddle themselves in the even and fill themselves to distension with the healthy nitrogenous food provide for them and the more they stoke the le exercise they take and more explosive they grow. then temper begin to wear away and men fell a brood over insult real or imaginary for they have nothing else to think of. the tone of the repartee change and instead of say light heartedly. i ll knock your silly face in men grow laboriously polite and hint that the cantonment be not big enough for themselves and their enemy and that there would he more space for one of the two in another place. 
it may have be the devil who arrange the thing but the fact of the case be that losson have for a long time be worry simmons in an aimless way. it give him occupation. the two have their cot side by side and would sometimes spend a long afternoon swear at each other. but simmons be afraid of losson and dare not challenge him to a fight. he think over the word in the hot still night and half the hate he felt toward losson be vent on the wretched punkah coolie. 
losson buy a parrot in the bazar and put it into a little cage and lower the cage into the cool darkness of a well and sit on the well curb shout bad language down to the parrot. he teach it to say. simmons ye so oor which mean swine and several other thing entirely unfit for publication. he be a big gross man and he shake like a jelly when the parrot have the sentence correctly. simmons however shake with rage for all the room be laugh at him the parrot be such a disreputable puff of green feather and it look so human when it chatter. losson use to sit swing his fat leg on the side of the cot and ask the parrot what it think of simmons. the parrot would answer. simmons ye so oor. good boy losson use to say scratch the parrot s head. ye ear that sim. 
and simmons use to turn over on his stomach and make answer. i ear. take eed you don t ear something one of these day. 
in the restless night after he have be asleep all day fit of blind rage come upon simmons and hold him till he tremble all over while he think in how many different way he would slay losson. sometimes he would picture himself trample the life out of the man with heavy ammunition boot and at others smash in his face with the butt and at others jump on his shoulder and drag the head back till the neckbone crack. then his mouth would feel hot and fevered and he would reach out for another sup of the beer in the pannikin. 
but the fancy that come to him most frequently and stay with him long be one connect with the great roll of fat under losson s right ear. he notice it first on a moonlight night and thereafter it be always before his eye. it be a fascinate roll of fat. a man could get his hand upon it and tear away one side of the neck. or he could place the muzzle of a rifle on it and blow away all the head in a flash. losson have no right to be sleek and content and well to do when he simmons be the butt of the room some day perhaps he would show those who laugh at the simmons ye so oor joke that he be a good a the rest and hold a man s life in the crook of his forefinger. when losson snore simmons hat him more bitterly than ever. why should losson be able to sleep when simmons have to stay awake hour after hour toss and turn on the tape with the dull liver pain gnaw into his right side and his head throb and ache after canteen. he think over this for many night and the world become unprofitable to him. he even blunt his naturally fine appetite with beer and tobacco. and all the while the parrot talk at and make a mock of him. 
the heat continue and the temper wear away more quickly than before. a sergeant s wife die of heat apoplexy in the night and the rumor run abroad that it be cholera. men rejoice openly hop that it would spread and send them into camp. but that be a false alarm. 
it be late on a tuesday even and the men be wait in the deep double veranda for last post when simmons go to the box at the foot of his bed take out his pipe and slam the lid down with a bang that echo through the desert barrack like the crack of a rifle. ordinarily speak the men would have take no notice. but their nerve be fret to fiddle string. they jump up and three or four clatter into the barrack room only to find simmons kneel by his box. 
owl it s you be it. they say and laugh foolishly. we t h o u g h t twas simmons rise slowly. if the accident have so shake his fellow what would not the reality do. 
you think it be do you. and what make you think. he say lash himself into madness a he go on. to hell with your think ye dirty spy.

then the instinct of the chase flare up. the news spread from barrack to barrack and the men double out intent on the capture of simmons the wild beast who be head for the cavalry parade grind stop now and again to send back a shoot and a curse in the direction of his pursuer.

an orderly bring a card to orde who take it with a movement of irritation at the interruption and band it to pagett. a large card with a rule border in red ink and in the centre in schoolboy copper plate mr. dma nath. give salaam say the civilian and there enter in haste a slender youth clothe in a closely fit coat of grey homespun tight trouser patent leather shoe and a small black velvet cap. his thin cheek twitch and his eye wander restlessly for the young man be evidently nervous and uncomfortable though strive to assume a free and easy air.

your father be a good man and i will do what i can for him.

curious very curious and callow. 
and yet the civilian reply one can scarcely help sympathize with him for his mere youth s sake. the young orator of the oxford union arrive at the same conclusion and show doubtless just the same enthusiasm. if there be any political analogy between india and england if the thousand race of this empire be one if there be any chance even of their learn to speak one language if in short india be a utopia of the debate room and not a real land this kind of talk might be worth listen to but it be all base on false analogy and ignorance of the fact.

but doe it succeed. do they make convert. 
they make no convert for the subtle oriental swallow the jam and reject the pill. but the mere example of the sober righteous and godly life of the principal and professor who be most excellent and devote men must have a certain moral value. yet a lord lansdowne point out the other day the market be dangerously overstock with graduate of our university who look for employment in the administration. an immense number be employ but year by year the college mill grind out increase list of youth foredoom to failure and disappointment and meanwhile trade manufacture and the industrial art be neglect and in fact regard with contempt by our new literary mandarin in posse.

this complaint about excessive growth of the army be akin to another contention of the congress party. they protest against the malversation of the whole of the money raise by additional tax a a famine insurance fund to other purpose. you must be aware that this special famine fund ha all be spend on frontier road and defence and strategic railway scheme a a protection against russia. 
but there be never a special famine fund raise by special taxation and put by a in a box. no sane administrator would dream of such a thing. in a time of prosperity a finance minister rejoice in a margin propose to annually apply a million and a half to the construction of railway and canal for the protection of district liable to scarcity and to the reduction of the annual loan for public work. but time be not always prosperous and the finance minister have to choose whether be would bang up the insurance scheme for a year or impose fresh taxation. when a farmer hasn t get the little surplus he hop to have for buy a new wagon and drain a low lie field corner you don t accuse him of malversation if he spend what he ha on the necessary work of the rest of his farm.

volume v plain tale from the hill. 
lispeth. 
look you have cast out love. what god be these you bid me please. the three in one the one in three. not so. to my own god i go. it may be they shall give me great ease than your cold christ and tangle trinity. the convert. 
she be the daughter of sonoo a hill man and jadeh his wife. one year their maize fail and two bear spend the night in their only poppy field just above the sutlej valley on the kotgarh side. so next season they turn christian and bring their baby to the mission to be baptize. the kotgarh chaplain christen her elizabeth and lispeth be the hill or pahari pronunciation. 
late cholera come into the kotgarh valley and carry off sonoo and jadeh and lispeth become half servant half companion to the wife of the then chaplain of kotgarh. this be after the reign of the moravian missionary but before kotgarh have quite forget her title of mistress of the northern hill. 
whether christianity improve lispeth or whether the god of her own people would have do a much for her under any circumstance i do not know. but she grow very lovely. when a hill girl grow lovely she be worth travel fifty mile over bad grind to look upon. lispeth have a greek face one of those face people paint so often and see so seldom. she be of a pale ivory color and for her race extremely tall. also she possess eye that be wonderful. and have she not be dress in the abominable print cloth affect by mission you would meet her on the hill side unexpectedly have think her the original diana of the roman go out to slay. 
lispeth take to christianity readily and do not abandon it when she reach womanhood a do some hill girl. her own people hat her because she have they say become a memsahib and wash herself daily. and the chaplain s wife do not know what to do with her. somehow one cannot ask a stately goddess five foot ten in her shoe to clean plate and dish. so she play with the chaplain s child and take class in the sunday school and read all the book in the house and grow more and more beautiful like the princess in fairy tale. the chaplain s wife say that the girl ought to take service in simla a a nurse or something genteel. but lispeth do not want to take service. she be very happy where she be. 
when traveller there be not many in those year come to kotgarh lispeth use to lock herself into her own room for fear they might take her away to simla or somewhere out into the unknown world. 
one day a few month after she be seventeen year old lispeth go out for a walk. she do not walk in the manner of english lady a mile and a half out and a ride back again. she cover between twenty and thirty mile in her little constitutional all about and about between kotgarh and narkunda. this time she come back at full dusk step down the breakneck descent into kotgarh with something heavy in her arm. the chaplain s wife be doze in the draw room when lispeth come in breathe hard and very exhaust with her burden. lispeth put it down on the sofa and say simply. 
this be my husband. i find him on the bagi road. he ha hurt himself. we will nurse him and when he be well your husband shall marry him to me. 
this be the first mention lispeth have ever make of her matrimonial view and the chaplain s wife shriek with horror. however the man on the sofa need attention first. he be a young englishman and his head have be cut to the bone by something jag. lispeth say she have find him down the khud so she have bring him in. 
he be breathe queerly and be unconscious. 
he be put to bed and tend by the chaplain who know something of medicine. and lispeth wait outside the door in case she could be useful. she explain to the chaplain that this be the man she mean to marry. and the chaplain and his wife lecture her severely on the impropriety of her conduct. lispeth listen quietly and repeat her first proposition. it take a great deal of christianity to wipe out uncivilized eastern instinct such a fall in love at first sight. lispeth have find the man she worship do not see why she should keep silent a to her choice. she have no intention of be send away either. she be go to nurse that englishman until he be well enough to marry her. this be her little programme. 
after a fortnight of slight fever and inflammation the englishman recover coherence and thank the chaplain and his wife and lispeth especially lispeth for their kindness. he be a traveller in the east he say they never talk about globe trotter in those day when the p. & o. fleet be young and small and have come from dehra dun to hunt for plant and butterfly among the simla hill. no one at simla therefore know anything about him. he fancy he must have fall over the cliff while stalk a fern on a rotten tree trunk and that his cooly must have steal his baggage and flee. he think he would go back to simla when he be a little strong. he desire no more mountaineer. 
he make small haste to go away and recover his strength slowly. 
lispeth object to be advise either by the chaplain or his wife. so the latter speak to the englishman and tell him how matter stand in lispeth s heart. he laugh a good deal and say it be very pretty and romantic a perfect idyl of the himalaya. but a he be engage to a girl at home he fancy that nothing would happen. certainly he would behave with discretion. he do that. still he find it very pleasant to talk to lispeth and walk with lispeth and say nice thing to her and call her pet name while he be get strong enough to go away. it mean nothing at all to him and everything in the world to lispeth. she be very happy while the fortnight last because she have find a man to love. 
be a savage by birth she take no trouble to hide her feeling and the englishman be amuse. when he go away lispeth walk with him up the hill a far a narkunda very trouble and very miserable. the chaplain s wife be a good christian and dislike anything in the shape of fuss or scandal lispeth be beyond her management entirely have tell the englishman to tell lispeth that he be come back to marry her. she be but a child you know and i fear at heart a heathen say the chaplain s wife. so all the twelve mile up the hill the englishman with his arm around lispeth s waist be assure the girl that he would come back and marry her. and lispeth make him promise over and over again. she weep on the narkunda ridge till he have pass out of sight along the muttiani path. 
then she dry her tear and go in to kotgarh again and say to the chaplain s wife. he will come back and marry me. he ha go to his own people to tell them so. and the chaplain s wife soothe lispeth and say. he will come back. at the end of two month lispeth grow impatient and be tell that the englishman have go over the sea to england. she know where england be because she have read little geography primer. but of course she have no conception of the nature of the sea be a hill girl. 
there be an old puzzle map of the world in the house. lispeth have play with it when she be a child. she unearth it again and put it together of evening and cry to herself and try to imagine where her englishman be. a she have no idea of distance or steamboat her notion be somewhat erroneous. it would not have make the least difference have she be perfectly correct. for the englishman have no intention of come back to marry a hill girl. he forget all about her by the time he be butterfly hunt in assam. he write a book on the east afterwards. lispeth s name do not appear. 
at the end of three month lispeth make daily pilgrimage to narkunda to see if her englishman be come along the road. it give her comfort and the chaplain s wife find her happy think that she be get over her barbarous and most indelicate folly. a little late the walk cease to help lispeth and her temper grow very bad. the chaplain s wife think this a profitable time to let her know the real state of affair that the englishman have only promise his love to keep her quiet that he have never mean anything and that it be wrong and improper of lispeth to think of marriage with an englishman who be of a superior clay besides be promise in marriage to a girl of his own people. lispeth say that all this be clearly impossible because he have say he love her and the chaplain s wife have with her own lip assert that the englishman be come back. 
how can what he and you say be untrue. ask lispeth. 
we say it a an excuse to keep you quiet child say the chaplain s wife. 
then you have lie to me say lispeth you and he. 
the chaplain s wife bow her head and say nothing. lispeth be silent too for a little time. then she go out down the valley and return in the dress of a hill girl infamously dirty but without the nose and ear ring. she have her hair braid into the long pig tail help out with black thread that hill woman wear. 
i be go back to my own people say she. you have kill lispeth. there be only leave old jadeh s daughter the daughter of a pahari and the servant of tarka devi. you be all liar you english. 
by the time that the chaplain s wife have recover from the shock of the announcement that lispeth have verted to her mother s god the girl have go. and she never come back. 
she take to her own unclean people savagely a if to make up the arrears of the life she have step out of. and in a little time she marry a wood cutter who beat her after the manner of paharis and her beauty fade soon. 
there be no law whereby you can account for the vagary of the heathen say the chaplain s wife and i believe that lispeth be always at heart an infidel. see she have be take into the church of england at the mature age of five week this statement doe not do credit to the chaplain s wife. 
lispeth be a very old woman when she die. she always have a perfect command of english and when she be sufficiently drink could sometimes be induce to tell the story of her first love affair. 
it be hard then to realize that the blear wrinkle creature so like a wisp of char rag could ever have be lispeth of the kotgarh mission.

after marriage arrive a reaction sometimes a big sometimes a little one. but it come sooner or late and must be tide over by both party if they desire the rest of their life to go with the current. 
in the case of the cusack bremmils this reaction do not set in till the third year after the wed. bremmil be hard to hold at the best of time. but he be a beautiful husband until the baby die and mr. bremmil wear black and grow thin and mourn a if the bottom of the universe have fall out. perhaps bremmil ought to have comfort her. he try to do so i think. but the more he comfort the more mr. bremmil grieve and consequently the more uncomfortable bremmil grow. the fact be that they both need a tonic. and they get it. mr. bremmil can afford to laugh now but it be no laugh matter to her at the time. 
you see mr. hauksbee appear on the horizon. and where she exist be fair chance of trouble. at simla her bye name be the stormy petrel. she have win that title five time to my own certain knowledge. she be a little brown thin almost skinny woman with big roll violet blue eye and the sweet manner in the world. you have only to mention her name at afternoon tea for every woman in the room to rise up and call her well not bless. she be clever witty brilliant and sparkle beyond most of her kind. but possess of many devil of malice and mischievousness. she could be nice though even to her own sex. but that be another story. 
bremmil go off at score after the baby s death and the general discomfort that follow and mr. hauksbee annex him. she take no pleasure in hide her captive. she annex him publicly and saw that the public saw it. he ride with her and walk with her and talk with her and picnic with her and tiffined at peliti s with her till people put up their eyebrow and say. shock. mr. bremmil stay at home turn over the dead baby s frock and cry into the empty cradle. she do not care to do anything else. but some eight dear affectionate lady friend explain the situation at length to her in case she should miss the cream of it. mr. bremmil listen quietly and thank them for their good office. she be not a clever a mr. hauksbee but she be no fool. she keep her own counsel and do not speak to bremmil of what she have hear. this be worth remember. speak to or cry over a husband never do any good yet. 
when bremmil be at home which be not often he be more affectionate than usual. and that show his hand. the affection be force partly to soothe his own conscience and partly to soothe mr. bremmil. it fail in both regard. 
then the a. d. c. in wait be command by their excellency lord and lady lytton to invite mr. and mr. cusack bremmil to peterhoff on july th at. p. m. dance in the bottom leave hand corner. 
i can t go say mr. bremmil it be too soon after poor little florrie but it need not stop you tom. 
she mean what she say then and bremmil say that he would go just to put in an appearance. here he speak the thing which be not. and mr. bremmil know it. she guess a woman s guess be much more accurate than a man s certainty that he have mean to go from the first and with mr. hauksbee. she sit down to think and the outcome of her thought be that the memory of a dead child be worth considerably le than the affection of a live husband. 
she make her plan and stake her all upon it. in that hour she discover that she know tom bremmil thoroughly and this knowledge she act on. 
tom say she i shall be din out at the longmores on the even of the th. you d good dine at the club. 
this save bremmil from make an excuse to get away and dine with mr. hauksbee so he be grateful and felt small and mean at the same time which be wholesome. bremmil leave the house at five for a ride. about half past five in the even a large leather cover basket come in from phelps for mr. bremmil. she be a woman who know how to dress. and she have not spend a week on design that dress and have it gore and hem and herring bone and tuck and ruck. or whatever the term be. for nothing. it be a gorgeous dress slight mourn. i can t describe it but it be what the queen call a creation a thing that hit you straight between the eye and make you gasp. she have not much heart for what she be go to do. but a she glance at the long mirror she have the satisfaction of know that she have never look so well in her life. she be a large blonde and when she choose carry herself superbly. 
after the dinner at the longmores she go on to the dance a little late and encounter bremmil with mr. hauksbee on his arm. 
that make her flush and a the men crowd round her for dance she look magnificent. she fill up all her dance except three and those she leave blank. mr. hauksbee catch her eye once. and she know it be war real war between them. she start handicap in the struggle for she have order bremmil about just the least little bite in the world too much. and he be begin to resent it. moreover he have never see his wife look so lovely. 
he star at her from doorway and glare at her from passage a she go about with her partner. and the more he star the more take be he. he could scarcely believe that this be the woman with the red eye and the black stuff gown who use to weep over the egg at breakfast. 
mr. hauksbee do her best to hold him in play but after two dance he cross over to his wife and ask for a dance. 
i m afraid you ve come too late mister bremmil she say with her eye twinkle. 
then he beg her to give him a dance and a a great favor she allow him the fifth waltz. luckily it stand vacant on his programme. they dance it together and there be a little flutter round the room. bremmil have a sort of notion that his wife could dance but he never know she dance so divinely. at the end of that waltz he ask for another a a favor not a a right. and mr. bremmil say. show me your programme dear. he show it a a naughty little schoolboy hand up contraband sweet to a master. 
there be a fair sprinkle of h on it besides h at supper. 
mr. bremmil say nothing but she smile contemptuously run her pencil through and two h s and return the card with her own name write above a pet name that only she and her husband use. then she shake her finger at him and say laugh. oh you silly silly boy. 
mr. hauksbee hear that and she own a much felt that she have the bad of it. bremmil accept and gratefully. they dance and sit out in one of the little tent. what bremmil say and what mr. bremmil say be no concern of any one s. 
when the band strike up the roast beef of old england the two go out into the verandah and bremmil begin look for his wife s dandy. this be before rickshaw day. while she go into the cloak room. mr. hauksbee come up and say. you take me in to supper i think mr. bremmil. bremmil turn red and look foolish. ah h m. i m go home with my wife mr. hauksbee. i think there ha be a little mistake. be a man he speak a though mr. hauksbee be entirely responsible.

to rear a boy under what parent call the shelter life system be if the boy must go into the world and fend for himself not wise. unless he be one in a thousand he ha certainly to pas through many unnecessary trouble. and may possibly come to extreme grief simply from ignorance of the proper proportion of thing. 
let a puppy eat the soap in the bath room or chew a newly black boot. he chew and chuckle until by and by he find out that black and old brown windsor make him very sick. so he argue that soap and boot be not wholesome. any old dog about the house will soon show him the unwisdom of bite big dog ear. be young he remember and go abroad at six month a well mannered little beast with a chasten appetite. if he have be keep away from boot and soap and big dog till he come to the trinity full grow and with develop teeth just consider how fearfully sick and thrash he would be. apply that motion to the shelter life and see how it work. it doe not sound pretty but it be the good of two evil. 
there be a boy once who have be bring up under the shelter life theory. and the theory kill him dead. he stay with his people all his day from the hour he be bear till the hour he go into sandhurst nearly at the top of the list. he be beautifully teach in all that win mark by a private tutor and carry the extra weight of never have give his parent an hour s anxiety in his life. what he learn at sandhurst beyond the regular routine be of no great consequence. he look about him and he find soap and black so to speak very good. he eat a little and come out of sandhurst not so high a he go in. 
them there be an interval and a scene with his people who expect much from him. next a year of live unspotted from the world in a third rate depot battalion where all the junior be child and all the senior old woman. and lastly he come out to india where he be cut off from the support of his parent and have no one to fall back on in time of trouble except himself. 
now india be a place beyond all others where one must not take thing too seriously the midday sun always except. too much work and too much energy kill a man just a effectively a too much assort vice or too much drink. flirtation doe not matter because every one be be transfer and either you or she leave the station and never return. good work doe not matter because a man be judge by his bad output and another man take all the credit of his best a a rule. bad work doe not matter because other men do bad and incompetent hang on long in india than anywhere else. amusement do not matter because you must repeat them a soon a you have accomplish them once and most amusement only mean try to win another person s money. 
sickness doe not matter because it s all in the day s work and if you die another man take over your place and your office in the eight hour between death and burial. nothing matter except home furlough and act allowance and these only because they be scarce. this be a slack kutcha country where all men work with imperfect instrument. and the wise thing be to take no one and nothing in earnest but to escape a soon a ever you can to some place where amusement be amusement and a reputation worth the have. 
but this boy the tale be a old a the hill come out and take all thing seriously. he be pretty and be pet. he take the petting seriously and fret over woman not worth saddle a pony to call upon. he find his new free life in india very good. 
it doe look attractive in the begin from a subaltern s point of view all pony partner dance and so on. he taste it a the puppy taste the soap. only he come late to the eat with a grow set of teeth. he have no sense of balance just like the puppy and could not understand why he be not treat with the consideration he receive under his father s roof. this hurt his feeling. 
he quarrel with other boy and be sensitive to the marrow remember these quarrel and they excite him. he find whist and gymkhana and thing of that kind. mean to amuse one after office. good. but he take them seriously too just a he take the head that follow after drink. he lose his money over whist and gymkhana because they be new to him. 
he take his loss seriously and waste a much energy and interest over a two gold mohur race for maiden ekka pony with their mane hog a if it have be the derby. one half of this come from inexperience much a the puppy squabble with the corner of the hearth rug and the other half from the dizziness breed by stumble out of his quiet life into the glare and excitement of a lively one. no one tell him about the soap and the black because an average man take it for grant that an average man be ordinarily careful in regard to them. it be pitiful to watch the boy knock himself to piece a an over handle colt fall down and cut himself when he get away from the groom. 
this unbridle license in amusement not worth the trouble of break line for much le riot over endure for six month all through one cold weather and then we think that the heat and the knowledge of have lose his money and health and lam his horse would sober the boy down and he would stand steady. in ninety nine case out of a hundred this would have happen. you can see the principle work in any indian station. but this particular case fell through because the boy be sensitive and take thing seriously a i may have say some seven time before. of course we couldn t tell how his excess strike him personally. 
they be nothing very heart break or above the average. he might be cripple for life financially and want a little nurse. 
still the memory of his performance would wither away in one hot weather and the shroff would help him to tide over the money trouble. but he must have take another view altogether and have believe himself ruin beyond redemption. his colonel talk to him severely when the cold weather end. that make him more wretched than ever. and it be only an ordinary colonel s wigging. 
what follow be a curious instance of the fashion in which we be all link together and make responsible for one another. the thing that kick the beam in the boy s mind be a remark that a woman make when he be talk to her. there be no use in repeat it for it be only a cruel little sentence rap out before think that make him flush to the root of his hair. he keep himself to himself for three day and then put in for two day leave to go shoot near a canal engineer s rest house about thirty mile out. he get his leave and that night at mess be noisy and more offensive than ever. he say that he be go to shoot big game and leave at half past ten o clock in an ekka. 
partridge which be the only thing a man could get near the rest house be not big game. so every one laugh. 
next morning one of the major come in from short leave and hear that the boy have go out to shoot big game. the major have take an interest in the boy and have more than once try to check him in the cold weather. the major put up his eyebrow when he hear of the expedition and go to the boy s room where he rummage. 
presently he come out and find me leave card on the mess. 
there be no one else in the ante room. 
he say. the boy ha go out shoot. doe a man shoot. 
@tetur with a revolver and a write case. 
i say. nonsense major. for i saw what be in his mind. 
he say. nonsense or nonsense i m go to the canal now at once. i don t feel easy. 
then he think for a minute and say. can you lie. 
you know best i answer. it s my profession. 
very well say the major. you must come out with me now at once in an ekka to the canal to shoot black buck. go and put on shikar kit quick and drive here with a gun. 
the major be a masterful man. and i know that he would not give order for nothing. so i obey and on return find the major pack up in an ekka gun case and food sling below all ready for a shoot trip. 
he dismiss the driver and drive himself. we jog along quietly while in the station. but a soon a we get to the dusty road across the plain he make that pony fly. a country breed can do nearly anything at a pinch. we cover the thirty mile in under three hour but the poor brute be nearly dead. 
once i say. what s the blaze hurry major. 
he say quietly. the boy ha be alone by himself for one two five fourteen hour now. i tell you i don t feel easy. 
this uneasiness spread itself to me and i help to beat the pony. 
when we come to the canal engineer s rest house the major call for the boy s servant. but there be no answer. then we go up to the house call for the boy by name. but there be no answer. 
oh he s out shoot say i. 
just then i saw through one of the window a little hurricane lamp burn. this be at four in the afternoon. we both stop dead in the verandah hold our breath to catch every sound. and we hear inside the room the brr brr brr of a multitude of fly. the major say nothing but he take off his helmet and we enter very softly. 
the boy be dead on the charpoy in the centre of the bare lime wash room. he have shoot his head nearly to piece with his revolver. the gun case be still strap so be the bed and on the table lay the boy s write case with photograph. he have go away to die like a poison rat. 
the major say to himself softly. poor boy. poor poor devil. then he turn away from the bed and say. i want your help in this business. 
know the boy be dead by his own hand i saw exactly what that help would be so i pass over to the table take a chair light a cheroot and begin to go through the write case. the major look over my shoulder and repeat to himself. we come too late. like a rat in a hole. poor poor devil. 
the boy must have spend half the night in write to his people and to his colonel and to a girl at home. and a soon a he have finish must have shoot himself for he have be dead a long time when we come in. 
i read all that he have write and pass over each sheet to the major a i finish it. 
we saw from his account how very seriously he have take everything. he write about disgrace which he be unable to bear indelible shame criminal folly waste life and so on. besides a lot of private thing to his father and mother too much too sacred to put into print. the letter to the girl at home be the most pitiful of all. and i choke a i read it. the major make no attempt to keep dry eye. i respect him for that. he read and rock himself to and fro and simply cry like a woman without care to hide it. the letter be so dreary and hopeless and touch. we forget all about the boy s folly and only think of the poor thing on the charpoy and the scrawl sheet in our hand. it be utterly impossible to let the letter go home. 
they would have break his father s heart and kill his mother after kill her belief in her son. 
at last the major dry his eye openly and say. nice sort of thing to spring on an english family. what shall we do. 
i say know what the major have bring me but for. the boy die of cholera. we be with him at the time. we can t commit ourselves to half measure. come along. 
then begin one of the most grimy comic scene i have ever take part in the concoction of a big write lie bolster with evidence to soothe the boy s people at home. i begin the rough draft of a letter the major throw in hint here and there while he gather up all the stuff that the boy have write and burn it in the fireplace. it be a hot still even when we begin and the lamp burn very badly. in due course i get the draft to my satisfaction set forth how the boy be the pattern of all virtue beloved by his regiment with every promise of a great career before him and so on. how we have help him through the sickness it be no time for little lie you will understand and how he have die without pain. i choke while i be put down these thing and think of the poor people who would read them. 
then i laugh at the grotesqueness of the affair and the laughter mix itself up with the choke and the major say that we both want drink. 
i be afraid to say how much whiskey we drink before the letter be finish. it have not the least effect on u. then we take off the boy s watch locket and ring. 
lastly the major say. we must send a lock of hair too. a woman value that. 
but there be reason why we could not find a lock fit to send. 
the boy be black haired and so be the major luckily. i cut off a piece of the major s hair above the temple with a knife and put it into the packet we be make. the laugh fit and the choke get hold of me again and i have to stop. the major be nearly a bad. and we both know that the bad part of the work be to come. 
we seal up the packet photograph locket seal ring letter and lock of hair with the boy s seal wax and the boy s seal. 
then the major say. for god s sake let s get outside away from the room and think. 
we go outside and walk on the bank of the canal for an hour eat and drink what we have with u until the moon rise. i know now exactly how a murderer feel. finally we force ourselves back to the room with the lamp and the other thing in it and begin to take up the next piece of work. i be not go to write about this. it be too horrible. we burn the bedstead and drop the ash into the canal. we take up the mat of the room and treat that in the same way. i go off to a village and borrow two big hoe i do not want the villager to help while the major arrange the other matter. it take u four hour hard work to make the grave. a we work we argue out whether it be right to say a much a we remember of the burial of the dead. 
we compromise thing by say the lord s prayer with a private unofficial prayer for the peace of the soul of the boy. then we fill in the grave and go into the verandah not the house to lie down to sleep. we be dead tire. 
when we wake the major say wearily. we can t go back till tomorrow. we must give him a decent time to die in. he die early this morning remember. that seem more natural. so the major must have be lie awake all the time think. 
i say. then why didn t we bring the body back to the cantonment. 
the major think for a minute. because the people bolt when they hear of the cholera. and the ekka ha go. 
that be strictly true. we have forget all about the ekka pony and he have go home. 
so we be leave there alone all that stifle day in the canal rest house test and re test our story of the boy s death to see if it be weak at any point. a native turn up in the afternoon but we say that a sahib be dead of cholera and he run away. a the dusk gather the major tell me all his fear about the boy and awful story of suicide or nearly carry out suicide tale that make one s hair crisp. he say that he himself have once go into the same valley of the shadow a the boy when he be young and new to the country. so he understand how thing fight together in the boy s poor jumble head. he also say that youngster in their repentant moment consider their sin much more serious and ineffaceable than they really be. we talk together all through the even and rehearse the story of the death of the boy. a soon a the moon be up and the boy theoretically just bury we strike across country for the station. we walk from eight till six o clock in the morning. but though we be dead tire we do not forget to go to the boy s room and put away his revolver with the proper amount of cartridge in the pouch. also to set his write case on the table. we find the colonel and report the death feel more like murderer than ever. then we go to bed and sleep the clock round. for there be no more in u. 
the tale have credence a long a be necessary for every one forget about the boy before a fortnight be over. many people however find time to say that the major have behave scandalously in not bring in the body for a regimental funeral. the sad thing of all be a letter from the boy s mother to the major and me with big inky blister all over the sheet. she write the sweet possible thing about our great kindness and the obligation she would be under to u a long a she live. 
all thing consider she be under an obligation. but not exactly a she mean.
