strickland be in the police and people do not understand him. so they say he be a doubtful sort of man and pass by on the other side. strickland have himself to thank for this. he hold the extraordinary theory that a policeman in india should try to know a much about the native a the native themselves. now in the whole of upper india there be only one man who can pas for hindu or mohammedan chamar or faquir a he plea. he be fear and respect by the native from the ghor kathri to the jamma musjid. and he be suppose to have the gift of invisibility and executive control over many devil. but what good ha this do him with the government. none in the world. he ha never get simla for his charge. and his name be almost unknown to englishman. 
strickland be foolish enough to take that man for his model. and follow out his absurd theory dabble in unsavory place no respectable man would think of explore all among the native riff raff. he educate himself in this peculiar way for seven year and people could not appreciate it. he be perpetually go fantee among the native which of course no man with any sense belief in. he be initiate into the sit bhai at allahabad once when he be on leave. he know the lizard song of the sansis and the halli hukk dance which be a religious can can of a startle kind. when a man know who dance the halli hukk and how and when and where he know something to be proud of. he ha go deep than the skin. but strickland be not proud though he have help once at jagadhri at the paint of the death bull which no englishman must even look upon. have master the thief patter of the changars. have take a eusufzai horse thief alone near attock. and have stand under the mimbar board of a border mosque and conduct service in the manner of a sunni mollah. 
his crown achievement be spend eleven day a a faquir in the garden of baba atal at amritsar and there pick up the thread of the great nasiban murder case. but people say justly enough. why on earth can t strickland sit in his office and write up his diary and recruit and keep quiet instead of show up the incapacity of his senior. so the nasiban murder case do him no good departmentally. but after his first feel of wrath he return to his outlandish custom of pry into native life. by the way when a man once acquire a taste for this particular amusement it abide with him all his day. it be the most fascinate thing in the world. love not except. where other men take ten day to the hill strickland take leave for what he call shikar put on the disguise that appeal to him at the time step down into the brown crowd and be swallow up for a while. he be a quiet dark young fellow spare black eye and when he be not think of something else a very interest companion. strickland on native progress a he have see it be worth hear. native hat strickland. but they be afraid of him. he know too much. 
when the youghals come into the station strickland very gravely a he do everything fell in love with miss youghal. and she after a while fell in love with him because she could not understand him. then strickland tell the parent. but mr. youghal say she be not go to throw her daughter into the bad pay department in the empire and old youghal say in so many word that he mistrust strickland s way and work and would thank him not to speak or write to his daughter any more. very well say strickland for he do not wish to make his lady love s life a burden. after one long talk with miss youghal he drop the business entirely. 
the youghals go up to simla in april. 
in july strickland secure three month leave on urgent private affair. he lock up his house though not a native in the providence would wittingly have touch estreekin sahib s gear for the world and go down to see a friend of his an old dyer at tarn taran. 
here all trace of him be lose until a sais meet me on the simla mall with this extraordinary note. 
dear old man. 
please give bearer a box of cheroot super no. i for preference. they be fresh at the club. i ll repay when i reappear. but at present i m out of society. 
yours. 
e. strickland. 
i order two box and hand them over to the sais with my love. 
that sais be strickland and he be in old youghal s employ attach to miss youghal s arab. the poor fellow be suffer for an english smoke and know that whatever happen i should hold my tongue till the business be over. 
late on mr. youghal who be wrap up in her servant begin talk at house where she call of her paragon among saises the man who be never too busy to get up in the morning and pick flower for the breakfast table and who black actually black the hoof of his horse like a london coachman. the turnout of miss youghal s arab be a wonder and a delight. strickland dulloo i mean find his reward in the pretty thing that miss youghal say to him when she go out rid. her parent be please to find she have forget all her foolishness for young strickland and say she be a good girl. 
strickland vow that the two month of his service be the most rigid mental discipline he ha ever go through. quite apart from the little fact that the wife of one of his fellow saises fell in love with him and then try to poison him with arsenic because he would have nothing to do with her he have to school himself into keep quiet when miss youghal go out rid with some man who try to flirt with her and he be force to trot behind carry the blanket and hear every word. also he have to keep his temper when he be slang in benmore porch by a policeman especially once when he be abuse by a naik he have himself recruit from isser jang village or bad still when a young subaltern call him a pig for not make way quickly enough. 
but the life have it compensation. he obtain great insight into the way and theft of saises enough he say to have summarily convict half the chamar population of the punjab if he have be on business. he become one of the lead player at knuckle bone which all jhampanis and many saises play while they be wait outside the government house or the gaiety theatre of night. he learn to smoke tobacco that be three fourth cowdung. and he hear the wisdom of the grizzle jemadar of the government house saises whose word be valuable. he saw many thing which amuse him. and he state on honor that no man can appreciate simla properly till he ha see it from the sais s point of view. 
he also say that if he choose to write all he saw his head would be break in several place. 
strickland s account of the agony he endure on wet night hear the music and see the light in benmore with his toe tingle for a waltz and his head in a horse blanket be rather amuse. one of these day strickland be go to write a little book on his experience. that book will be worth buy. and even more worth suppress. 
thus he serve faithfully a jacob serve for rachel. and his leave be nearly at an end when the explosion come. he have really do his best to keep his temper in the hear of the flirtation i have mention. but he break down at last. an old and very distinguish general take miss youghal for a ride and begin that specially offensive you re only a little girl sort of flirtation most difficult for a woman to turn aside deftly and most madden to listen to. miss youghal be shake with fear at the thing he say in the hear of her sais. dulloo strickland stand it a long a he could. then he catch hold of the general s bridle and in most fluent english invite him to step off and be heave over the cliff. next minute miss youghal begin cry. and strickland saw that he have hopelessly give himself away and everything be over. 
the general nearly have a fit while miss youghal be sob out the story of the disguise and the engagement that wasn t recognize by the parent. strickland be furiously angry with himself and more angry with the general for force his hand. so he say nothing but hold the horse s head and prepare to thrash the general a some sort of satisfaction but when the general have thoroughly grasp the story and know who strickland be he begin to puff and blow in the saddle and nearly roll off with laugh. he say strickland deserve a v. c. if it be only for put on a sais s blanket. then he call himself name and vow that he deserve a thrash but he be too old to take it from strickland. then he compliment miss youghal on her lover. 
the scandal of the business never strike him. for he be a nice old man with a weakness for flirtation. then he laugh again and say that old youghal be a fool. strickland let go of the cob s head and suggest that the general have good help them if that be his opinion. strickland know youghal s weakness for men with title and letter after their name and high official position. 
it s rather like a forty minute farce say the general but begad i will help if it s only to escape that tremendous thrash i deserve. go along to your home my sais policeman and change into decent kit and i ll attack mr. youghal. miss youghal may i ask you to canter home and wait. 
about seven minute late there be a wild hurroosh at the club. 
a sais with a blanket and head rope be ask all the men he know. for heaven s sake lend me decent clothe. a the men do not recognize him there be some peculiar scene before strickland could get a hot bath with soda in it in one room a shirt here a collar there a pair of trouser elsewhere and so on. he gallop off with half the club wardrobe on his back and an utter strange s pony under him to the house of old youghal. 
the general array in purple and fine linen be before him. 
what the general have say strickland never know but youghal receive strickland with moderate civility. and mr. youghal touch by the devotion of the transform dulloo be almost kind. 
the general beam and chuckle and miss youghal come in and almost before old youghal know where he be the parental consent have be wrench out and strickland have depart with miss youghal to the telegraph office to wire for his kit. the final embarrassment be when an utter strange attack him on the mall and ask for the steal pony. 
so in the end strickland and miss youghal be marry on the strict understand that strickland should drop his old way and stick to departmental routine which pay best and lead to simla. 
strickland be far too fond of his wife just then to break his word but it be a sore trial to him. for the street and the bazar and the sound in them be full of mean to strickland and these call to him to come back and take up his wandering and his discovery. some day i will tell you how he break his promise to help a friend. that be long since and he ha by this time be nearly spoil for what he would call shikar. he be forget the slang and the beggar s cant and the mark and the sign and the drift of the undercurrent which if a man would master he must always continue to learn. 
but he fill in his departmental return beautifully. 
yoke with an unbeliever. 
i be die for you and you be die for another. punjabi proverb. 
when the gravesend tender leave the p. &. steamer for bombay and go back to catch the train to town there be many people in it cry. but the one who weep most and most openly be miss agnes laiter. she have reason to cry because the only man she ever love or ever could love so she say be go out to india. and india a every one know be divide equally between jungle tiger cobra cholera and sepoys. 
phil garron lean over the side of the steamer in the rain felt very unhappy too. but he do not cry. he be send out to tea. what tea mean he have not the vague idea but fancy that he would have to ride on a prance horse over hill cover with tea vine and draw a sumptuous salary for do so. and he be very grateful to his uncle for get him the berth. he be really go to reform all his slack shiftless way save a large proportion of his magnificent salary yearly and in a very short time return to marry agnes laiter. phil garron have be lie loose on his friend hand for three year and a he have nothing to do he naturally fell in love. he be very nice. but he be not strong in his view and opinion and principle and though he never come to actual grief his friend be thankful when he say good bye and go out to this mysterious tea business near darjiling. they say. god bless you dear boy. let u never see your face again or at least that be what phil be give to understand. 
when he sail he be very full of a great plan to prove himself several hundred time good than any one have give him credit for to work like a horse and triumphantly marry agnes laiter. he have many good point besides his good look. his only fault be that he be weak the least little bite in the world weak. he have a much notion of economy a the morning sun. and yet you could not lay your hand on any one item and say. herein phil garron be extravagant or reckless. nor could you point out any particular vice in his character. but he be unsatisfactory and a workable a putty. 
agnes laiter go about her duty at home her family object to the engagement with red eye while phil be sail to darjiling a port on the bengal ocean a his mother use to tell her friend. he be popular enough on board ship make many acquaintance and a moderately large liquor bill and send off huge letter to agnes laiter at each port. then he fell to work on this plantation somewhere between darjiling and kangra and though the salary and the horse and the work be not quite all he have fancy he succeed fairly well and give himself much unnecessary credit for his perseverance. 
in the course of time a he settle more into collar and his work grow fix before him the face of agnes laiter go out of his mind and only come when he be at leisure which be not often. he would forget all about her for a fortnight and remember her with a start like a school boy who ha forget to learn his lesson. 
she do not forget phil because she be of the kind that never forget. only another man a really desirable young man present himself before mr. laiter. and the chance of a marriage with phil be a far off a ever. and his letter be so unsatisfactory. and there be a certain amount of domestic pressure bring to bear on the girl. and the young man really be an eligible person a income go. and the end of all thing be that agnes marry him and write a tempestuous whirlwind of a letter to phil in the wild of darjiling and say she should never know a happy moment all the rest of her life. which be a true prophecy. 
phil get that letter and hold himself ill treat. this be two year after he have come out. but by dint of think fixedly of agnes laiter and look at her photograph and pat himself on the back for be one of the most constant lover in history and warm to the work a he go on he really fancy that he have be very hardly use. he sit down and write one final letter a really pathetic world without end amen epistle. explain how he would be true to eternity and that all woman be very much alike and he would hide his break heart etc. etc. but if at any future time etc. etc. he could afford to wait etc. etc. unchanged affection etc. etc. return to her old love etc. etc. for eight closely write page. from an artistic point of view it be very neat work but an ordinary philistine who know the state of phil s real feeling not the one he rise to a he go on write would have call it the thoroughly mean and selfish work of a thoroughly mean and selfish weak man. but this verdict would have be incorrect. phil pay for the postage and felt every word he have write for at least two day and a half. 
it be the last flicker before the light go out. 
that letter make agnes laiter very unhappy and she cry and put it away in her desk and become mr. somebody else for the good of her family. which be the first duty of every christian maid. 
phil go his way and think no more of his letter except a an artist think of a neatly touch in sketch. his way be not bad but they be not altogether good until they bring him across dunmaya the daughter of a rajput ex subadar major of our native army. the girl have a strain of hill blood in her and like the hill woman be not a purdah nashin. where phil meet her or how he hear of her doe not matter. she be a good girl and handsome and in her way very clever and shrewd. though of course a little hard. it be to be remember that phil be live very comfortably deny himself no small luxury never put by an anna very satisfy with himself and his good intention be drop all his english correspondent one by one and begin more and more to look upon this land a his home. some men fall this way. and they be of no use afterwards. the climate where he be station be good and it really do not seem to him that there be anything to go home for. 
he do what many planter have do before him that be to say he make up his mind to marry a hill girl and settle down. he be seven and twenty then with a long life before him but no spirit to go through with it. so he marry dunmaya by the form of the english church and some fellow planter say he be a fool and some say he be a wise man. dunmaya be a thoroughly honest girl and in spite of her reverence for an englishman have a reasonable estimate of her husband s weakness. she manage him tenderly and become in le than a year a very passable imitation of an english lady in dress and carriage. [it be curious to think that a hill man after a lifetime s education be a hill man still. but a hill woman can in six month master most of the way of her english sister. there be a coolie woman once. but that be another story. ] dunmaya dress by preference in black and yellow and look well. 
meantime the letter lay in agnes s desk and now and again she would think of poor resolute hard work phil among the cobra and tiger of darjiling toil in the vain hope that she might come back to him. her husband be worth ten phils except that he have rheumatism of the heart. three year after he be marry and after he have try nice and algeria for his complaint he go to bombay where he die and set agnes free. be a devout woman she look on his death and the place of it a a direct interposition of providence and when she have recover from the shock she take out and reread phil s letter with the etc. etc. and the big dash and the little dash and kiss it several time. no one know her in bombay. she have her husband s income which be a large one and phil be close at hand. it be wrong and improper of course but she decide a heroine do in novel to find her old lover to offer him her hand and her gold and with him spend the rest of her life in some spot far from unsympathetic soul. she sit for two month alone in watson s hotel elaborate this decision and the picture be a pretty one. then she set out in search of phil garron assistant on a tea plantation with a more than usually unpronounceable name. 
she find him. she spend a month over it for his plantation be not in the darjiling district at all but near kangra. phil be very little alter and dunmaya be very nice to her. 
now the particular sin and shame of the whole business be that phil who really be not worth think of twice be and be love by dunmaya and more than love by agnes the whole of whose life he seem to have spoil. 
bad of all dunmaya be make a decent man of him. and he will be ultimately save from perdition through her train. 
which be manifestly unfair. 
false dawn. 
tonight god know what thing shall tide the earth be rack and faint expectant sleepless open eye. and we who from the earth be make thrill with our mother s pain. in durance. 
no man will ever know the exact truth of this story. though woman may sometimes whisper it to one another after a dance when they be put up their hair for the night and compare list of victim. a man of course cannot assist at these function. so the tale must be tell from the outside in the dark all wrong. 
never praise a sister to a sister in the hope of your compliment reach the proper ear and so prepare the way for you late on. sister be woman first and sister afterwards. and you will find that you do yourself harm. 
saumarez know this when he make up his mind to propose to the elder miss copleigh. saumarez be a strange man with few merit so far a men could see though he be popular with woman and carry enough conceit to stock a viceroy s council and leave a little over for the commander in chief s staff. he be a civilian. very many woman take an interest in saumarez perhaps because his manner to them be offensive. if you hit a pony over the nose at the outset of your acquaintance he may not love you but he will take a deep interest in your movement ever afterwards. the elder miss copleigh be nice plump win and pretty. the young be not so pretty and from men disregard the hint set forth above her style be repellant and unattractive. both girl have practically the same figure and there be a strong liken between them in look and voice. though no one could doubt for an instant which be the nice of the two. 
saumarez make up his mind a soon a they come into the station from behar to marry the elder one. at least we all make sure that he would which come to the same thing. she be two and twenty and he be thirty three with pay and allowance of nearly fourteen hundred rupee a month. so the match a we arrange it be in every way a good one. saumarez be his name and summary be his nature a a man once say. have draft his resolution he form a select committee of one to sit upon it and resolve to take his time. in our unpleasant slang the copleigh girl hunt in couple. that be to say you could do nothing with one without the other. they be very love sister. but their mutual affection be sometimes inconvenient. saumarez hold the balance hair true between them and none but himself could have say to which side his heart incline. though every one guess. he ride with them a good deal and dance with them but he never succeed in detach them from each other for any length of time. 
woman say that the two girl keep together through deep mistrust each fear that the other would steal a march on her. but that ha nothing to do with a man. saumarez be silent for good or bad and a. 
@business likely attentive a he could be have due regard to his work and his polo. beyond doubt both girl be fond of him. 
a the hot weather draw near and saumarez make no sign woman say that you could see their trouble in the eye of the girl that they be look strain anxious and irritable. men be quite blind in these matter unless they have more of the woman than the man in their composition in which case it doe not matter what they say or think. i maintain it be the hot april day that take the color out of the copleigh girl cheek. they should have be send to the hill early. no one man or woman feel an angel when the hot weather be approach. the young sister grow more cynical not to say acid in her way. and the winningness of the elder wear thin. there be more effort in it. 
now the station wherein all these thing happen be though not a little one off the line of rail and suffer through want of attention. there be no garden or band or amusement worth speak of and it be nearly a day s journey to come into lahore for a dance. people be grateful for small thing to interest them. 
about the begin of may and just before the final exodus of hill goer when the weather be very hot and there be not more than twenty people in the station saumarez give a moonlight rid picnic at an old tomb six mile away near the bed of the river. it be a noah s ark picnic. and there be to be the usual arrangement of quarter mile interval between each couple on account of the dust. six couple come altogether include chaperon. moonlight picnic be useful just at the very end of the season before all the girl go away to the hill. they lead to understanding and should be encourage by chaperone. especially those whose girl look sweetish in rid habit. i know a case once. but that be another story. that picnic be call the great pop picnic because every one know saumarez would propose then to the eldest miss copleigh. and beside his affair there be another which might possibly come to happiness. 
the social atmosphere be heavily charge and want clear. 
we meet at the parade grind at ten. the night be fearfully hot. 
the horse sweat even at walk pace but anything be good than sit still in our own dark house. when we move off under the full moon we be four couple one triplet and mr. saumarez ride with the copleigh girl and i loiter at the tail of the procession wonder with whom saumarez would ride home. every one be happy and content. but we all felt that thing be go to happen. we ride slowly. and it be nearly midnight before we reach the old tomb face the ruin tank in the decay garden where we be go to eat and drink. i be late in come up. and before i go into the garden i saw that the horizon to the north carry a faint dun color feather. but no one would have thank me for spoil so well manage an entertainment a this picnic and a dust storm more or le doe no great harm. 
we gather by the tank. some one have bring out a banjo which be a most sentimental instrument and three or four of u sing. 
you must not laugh at this. our amusement in out of the way station be very few indeed. then we talk in group or together lie under the tree with the sun bake rose drop their petal on our foot until supper be ready. it be a beautiful supper a cold and a ice a you could wish. and we stay long over it. 
i have felt that the air be grow hot and hot. but nobody seem to notice it until the moon go out and a burn hot wind begin lash the orange tree with a sound like the noise of the sea. before we know where we be the dust storm be on u and everything be roar whirl darkness. the supper table be blow bodily into the tank. we be afraid of stay anywhere near the old tomb for fear it might be blow down. so we felt our way to the orange tree where the horse be picket and wait for the storm to blow over. then the little light that be leave vanish and you could not see your hand before your face. the air be heavy with dust and sand from the bed of the river that fill boot and pocket and drift down neck and coat eyebrow and moustache. it be one of the bad dust storm of the year. 
we be all huddle together close to the tremble horse with the thunder clatter overhead and the lightning spurt like water from a sluice all way at once. there be no danger of course unless the horse break loose. i be stand with my head downward and my hand over my mouth hear the tree thrash each other. i could not see who be next me till the flash come. 
then i find that i be pack near saumarez and the eldest miss copleigh with my own horse just in front of me. i recognize the eldest miss copleigh because she have a pagri round her helmet and the young have not. all the electricity in the air have go into my body and i be quiver and tingle from head to foot exactly a a corn shoot and tingle before rain. it be a grand storm. 
the wind seem to be pick up the earth and pitch it to leeward in great heap. and the heat beat up from the grind like the heat of the day of judgment. 
the storm lull slightly after the first half hour and i hear a despair little voice close to my ear say to itself quietly and softly a if some lose soul be fly about with the wind. o my god. then the young miss copleigh stumble into my arm say. where be my horse. get my horse. i want to go home. i want to go home. take me home. 
i think that the lightning and the black darkness have frighten her. so i say there be no danger but she must wait till the storm blow over. she answer. it be not that. it be not that. i want to go home. o take me away from here. 
i say that she could not go till the light come. but i felt her brush past me and go away. it be too dark to see where. then the whole sky be split open with one tremendous flash a if the end of the world be come and all the woman shriek. 
almost directly after this i felt a man s hand on my shoulder and hear saumarez bellow in my ear. through the rattle of the tree and howl of the wind i do not catch his word at once but at last i hear him say. i ve propose to the wrong one. what shall i do. saumarez have no occasion to make this confidence to me. i be never a friend of his nor be i now. but i fancy neither of u be ourselves just then. he be shake a he stand with excitement and i be feel queer all over with the electricity. 
i could not think of anything to say except. more fool you for propose in a dust storm. but i do not see how that would improve the mistake. 
then he shout. where s edith edith copleigh. edith be the young sister. i answer out of my astonishment. what do you want with her. would you believe it for the next two minute he and i be shout at each other like maniac he vow that it be the young sister he have mean to propose to all along and i tell him till my throat be hoarse that he must have make a mistake. i can t account for this except again by the fact that we be neither of u ourselves. everything seem to me like a bad dream from the stamp of the horse in the darkness to saumarez tell me the story of his love edith copleigh since the first. he be still claw my shoulder and beg me to tell him where edith copleigh be when another lull come and bring light with it and we saw the dust cloud form on the plain in front of u. so we know the bad be over. the moon be low down and there be just the glimmer of the false dawn that come about an hour before the real one. but the light be very faint and the dun cloud roar like a bull. i wonder where edith copleigh have go. and a i be wonder i saw three thing together. first maud copleigh s face come smile out of the darkness and move towards saumarez who be stand by me. i hear the girl whisper george and slide her arm through the arm that be not claw my shoulder and i saw that look on her face which only come once or twice in a lifetime when a woman be perfectly happy and the air be full of trumpet and gorgeous color fire and the earth turn into cloud because she love and be love. at the same time i saw saumarez s face a he hear maud copleigh s voice and fifty yard away from the clump of orange tree i saw a brown holland habit get upon a horse. 
it must have be my state of over excitement that make me so quick to meddle with what do not concern me. saumarez be move off to the habit. but i push him back and say. stop here and explain. i ll fetch her back. and i run out to get at my own horse. i have a perfectly unnecessary notion that everything must be do decently and in order and that saumarez s first care be to wipe the happy look out of maud copleigh s face. all the time i be link up the curb chain i wonder how he would do it. 
i canter after edith copleigh think to bring her back slowly on some pretence or another. but she gallop away a soon a she saw me and i be force to ride after her in earnest. she call back over her shoulder go away. i m go home. oh go away. two or three time. but my business be to catch her first and argue late. the ride just fit in with the rest of the evil dream. the grind be very bad and now and again we rush through the whirl choke dust devil in the skirt of the fly storm. there be a burn hot wind blow that bring up a stench of stale brick kiln with it. and through the half light and through the dust devil across that desolate plain flicker the brown holland habit on the gray horse. she head for the station at first. then she wheel round and set off for the river through bed of burn down jungle grass bad even to ride a pig over. in cold blood i should never have dream of go over such a country at night but it seem quite right and natural with the lightning crackle overhead and a reek like the smell of the pit in my nostril. i ride and shout and she bend forward and lash her horse and the aftermath of the dust storm come up and catch u both and drive u downwind like piece of paper. 
i don t know how far we ride. but the drum of the horse hoof and the roar of the wind and the race of the faint blood red moon through the yellow mist seem to have go on for year and year and i be literally drench with sweat from my helmet to my gaiter when the gray stumble recover himself and pull up dead lame. my brute be use up altogether. edith copleigh be in a sad state plaster with dust her helmet off and cry bitterly. why can t you let me alone. she say. i only want to get away and go home. oh please let me go. 
you have get to come back with me miss copleigh. saumarez ha something to say to you. 
it be a foolish way of put it. but i hardly know miss copleigh. and though i be play providence at the cost of my horse i could not tell her in a many word what saumarez have tell me. i think he could do that good himself. all her pretence about be tire and want to go home break down and she rock herself to and fro in the saddle a she sob and the hot wind blow her black hair to leeward. i be not go to repeat what she say because she be utterly unstring. 
this if you please be the cynical miss copleigh. here be i almost an utter strange to her try to tell her that saumarez love her and she be to come back to hear him say so. i believe i make myself understand for she gather the gray together and make him hobble somehow and we set off for the tomb while the storm go thunder down to umballa and a few big drop of warm rain fell. i find out that she have be stand close to saumarez when he propose to her sister and have want to go home and cry in peace a an english girl should. she dabble her eye with her pocket handkerchief a we go along and babble to me out of sheer lightness of heart and hysteria. that be perfectly unnatural. and yet it seem all right at the time and in the place. all the world be only the two copleigh girl saumarez and i ring in with the lightning and the dark. and the guidance of this misguide world seem to lie in my hand. 
when we return to the tomb in the deep dead stillness that follow the storm the dawn be just break and nobody have go away. they be wait for our return. saumarez most of all. 
his face be white and draw. a miss copleigh and i limp up he come forward to meet u and when he help her down from her saddle he kiss her before all the picnic. it be like a scene in a theatre and the liken be heighten by all the dust white ghostly look men and woman under the orange tree clap their hand a if they be watch a play at saumarez s choice. i never know anything so un english in my life. 
lastly saumarez say we must all go home or the station would come out to look for u and would i be good enough to ride home with maud copleigh. nothing would give me great pleasure i say. 
so we form up six couple in all and go back two by two. saumarez walk at the side of edith copleigh who be rid his horse. 
the air be clear. and little by little a the sun rise i felt we be all drop back again into ordinary men and woman and that the great pop picnic be a thing altogether apart and out of the world never to happen again. it have go with the dust storm and the tingle in the hot air. 
i felt tire and limp and a good deal ashamed of myself a i go in for a bath and some sleep. 
there be a woman s version of this story but it will never be write. unless maud copleigh care to try. 
the rescue of pluffles. 
thus for a season they fight it fair she and his cousin may tactful talented debonnaire decorous foe be they. but never can battle of man compare with merciless feminine fray. two and one. 
mr. hauksbee be sometimes nice to her own sex. here be a story to prove this. and you can believe just a much a ever you please. 
pluffles be a subaltern in the unmentionable. he be callow even for a subaltern. he be callow all over like a canary that have not finish fledge itself. the bad of it be he have three time a much money a be good for him. pluffles papa be a rich man and pluffles be the only son. pluffles mamma adore him. she be only a little le callow than pluffles and she believe everything he say. 
pluffles weakness be not believe what people say. he prefer what he call trust to his own judgment. he have a much judgment a he have seat or hand. and this preference tumble him into trouble once or twice. but the big trouble pluffles ever manufacture come about at simla some year ago when he be four and twenty. 
he begin by trust to his own judgment a usual and the result be that after a time he be bind hand and foot to mr. reiver s rickshaw wheel. 
there be nothing good about mr. reiver unless it be her dress. 
she be bad from her hair which start life on a brittany s girl s head to her boot heel which be two and three eighth inch high. she be not honestly mischievous like mr. hauksbee. she be wicked in a business like way. 
there be never any scandal she have not generous impulse enough for that. she be the exception which prove the rule that anglo indian lady be in every way a nice a their sister at home. 
she spend her life in prove that rule. 
mr. hauksbee and she hat each other fervently. they hear far too much to clash. but the thing they say of each other be startle not to say original. mr. hauksbee be honest honest a her own front teeth and but for her love of mischief would have be a woman s woman. there be no honesty about mr. reiver. nothing but selfishness. and at the begin of the season poor little pluffles fell a prey to her. she lay herself out to that end and who be pluffles to resist. he go on trust to his judgment and he get judge. 
i have see hay argue with a tough horse i have see a tonga driver coerce a stubborn pony i have see a riotous setter break to gun by a hard keeper but the break in of pluffles of the unmentionable be beyond all these. he learn to fetch and carry like a dog and to wait like one too for a word from mr. reiver. he learn to keep appointment which mr. reiver have no intention of keep. he learn to take thankfully dance which mr. reiver have no intention of give him. he learn to shiver for an hour and a quarter on the windward side of elysium while mr. reiver be make up her mind to come for a ride. he learn to hunt for a rickshaw in a light dress suit under a pelt rain and to walk by the side of that rickshaw when he have find it. he learn what it be to be speak to like a coolie and order about like a cook. he learn all this and many other thing besides. and he pay for his school. 
perhaps in some hazy way he fancy that it be fine and impressive that it give him a status among men and be altogether the thing to do. it be nobody s business to warn pluffles that he be unwise. the pace that season be too good to inquire. and meddle with another man s folly be always thankless work. 
pluffles colonel should have order him back to his regiment when he hear how thing be go. but pluffles have get himself engage to a girl in england the last time he go home. and if there be one thing more than another which the colonel detest it be a marry subaltern. he chuckle when he hear of the education of pluffles and say it be good train for the boy. but it be not good train in the least. it lead him into spend money beyond his mean which be good. above that the education spoil an average boy and make it a tenth rate man of an objectionable kind. he wander into a bad set and his little bill at hamilton s be a thing to wonder at. 
then mr. hauksbee rise to the occasion. she play her game alone know what people would say of her. and she play it for the sake of a girl she have never see. pluffles fiancee be to come out under the chaperonage of an aunt in october to be marry to pluffles. 
at the begin of august mr. hauksbee discover that it be time to interfere. a man who ride much know exactly what a horse be go to do next before he doe it. in the same way a woman of mr. hauksbee s experience know accurately how a boy will behave under certain circumstance notably when he be infatuate with one of mr. reiver s stamp. she say that sooner or late little pluffles would break off that engagement for nothing at all simply to gratify mr. reiver who in return would keep him at her foot and in her service just so long a she find it worth her while. 
she say she know the sign of these thing. if she do not no one else could. 
then she go forth to capture pluffles under the gun of the enemy. just a mr. cusack bremmil carry away bremmil under mr. hauksbee s eye. 
this particular engagement last seven week we call it the seven week war and be fight out inch by inch on both side. a detail account would fill a book and would be incomplete then. 
any one who know about these thing can fit in the detail for himself. it be a superb fight there will never be another like it a long a jakko stand and pluffles be the prize of victory. 
people say shameful thing about mr. hauksbee. they do not know what she be play for. mr. reiver fight partly because pluffles be useful to her but mainly because she hat mr. hauksbee and the matter be a trial of strength between them. no one know what pluffles think. he have not many idea at the best of time and the few he possess make him conceited. mr. hauksbee say. the boy must be catch. and the only way of catch him be by treat him well. 
so she treat him a a man of the world and of experience so long a the issue be doubtful. little by little pluffles fell away from his old allegiance and come over to the enemy by whom he be make much of. he be never send on out post duty after rickshaw any more nor be he give dance which never come off nor be the drain on his purse continue. mr. hauksbee hold him on the snaffle. and after his treatment at mr. reiver s hand he appreciate the change. 
mr. reiver have break him of talk about himself and make him talk about her own merit. mr. hauksbee act otherwise and win his confidence till he mention his engagement to the girl at home speak of it in a high and mighty way a a piece of boyish folly. this be when he be take tea with her one afternoon and discourse in what he consider a gay and fascinate style. 
mr. hauksbee have see an early generation of his stamp bud and blossom and decay into fat captain and tubby major. 
at a moderate estimate there be about three and twenty side to that lady s character. some men say more. she begin to talk to pluffles after the manner of a mother and a if there have be three hundred year instead of fifteen between them. she speak with a sort of throaty quaver in her voice which have a soothe effect though what she say be anything but soothe. she point out the exceed folly not to say meanness of pluffles conduct and the smallness of his view. then he stammer something about trust to his own judgment a a man of the world. and this pave the way for what she want to say next. it would have wither up pluffles have it come from any other woman. but in the soft coo style in which mr. hauksbee put it it only make him feel limp and repentant a if he have be in some superior kind of church. little by little very softly and pleasantly she begin take the conceit out of pluffles a you take the rib out of an umbrella before re cover it. she tell him what she think of him and his judgment and his knowledge of the world. and how his performance have make him ridiculous to other people. and how it be his intention to make love to herself if she give him the chance. then she say that marriage would be the make of him. and draw a pretty little picture all rise and opal of the mr. pluffles of the future go through life rely on the judgment and knowledge of the world of a husband who have nothing to reproach himself with. how she reconcile these two statement she alone know. but they do not strike pluffles a conflict. 
hers be a perfect little homily much good than any clergyman could have give and it end with touch allusion to pluffles mamma and papa and the wisdom of take his bride home. 
then she send pluffles out for a walk to think over what she have say. pluffles leave blow his nose very hard and hold himself very straight. mr. hauksbee laugh. 
what pluffles have intend to do in the matter of the engagement only mr. reiver know and she keep her own counsel to her death. she would have like it spoil a a compliment i fancy. 
pluffles enjoy many talk with mr. hauksbee during the next few day. they be all to the same end and they help pluffles in the path of virtue. 
mr. hauksbee want to keep him under her wing to the last. 
therefore she discountenance his go down to bombay to get marry. goodness only know what might happen by the way. she say. pluffles be curse with the curse of reuben and india be no fit place for him. 
in the end the fiancee arrive with her aunt. and pluffles have reduce his affair to some sort of order here again mr. hauksbee help him be marry. 
mr. hauksbee give a sigh of relief when both the i will have be say and go her way. 
pluffles take her advice about go home. he leave the service and be now raise speckle cattle inside green paint fence somewhere at home. i believe he doe this very judiciously. he would have come to extreme grief out here. 
for these reason if any one say anything more than usually nasty about mr. hauksbee tell him the story of the rescue of pluffles.

once upon a time there live at simla a very pretty girl the daughter of a poor but honest district and session judge. she be a good girl but could not help know her power and use it. 
her mamma be very anxious about her daughter s future a all good mamma should be. 
when a man be a commissioner and a bachelor and ha the right of wear open work jam tart jewel in gold and enamel on his clothe and of go through a door before every one except a member of council a lieutenant governor or a viceroy he be worth marry. at least that be what lady say. there be a commissioner in simla in those day who be and wear and do all i have say. he be a plain man an ugly man the ugly man in asia with two exception. his be a face to dream about and try to carve on a pipe head afterwards. his name be saggott barr saggott anthony barr saggott and six letter to follow. 
departmentally he be one of the best men the government of india own. socially he be like a blandish gorilla. 
when he turn his attention to miss beighton i believe that mr. 
beighton weep with delight at the reward providence have send her in her old age. 
mr. beighton hold his tongue. he be an easy go man. 
now a commissioner be very rich. his pay be beyond the dream of avarice be so enormous that he can afford to save and scrape in a way that would almost discredit a member of council. most commissioner be mean. but barr saggott be an exception. he entertain royally. he horse himself well. he give dance. he be a power in the land. and he behave a such. 
consider that everything i be write of take place in an almost pre historic era in the history of british india. some folk may remember the year before lawn tennis be bear when we all play croquet. there be season before that if you will believe me when even croquet have not be invent and archery which be revive in england in be a great a pest a lawn tennis be now. people talk learnedly about hold and loose stele reflexed bow pound bow back or self yew bow a we talk about rally volley smash return and ounce racket. 
miss beighton shoot divinely over lady distance yard that be and be acknowledge the best lady archer in simla. men call her diana of tara devi. 
barr saggott pay her great attention. and a i have say the heart of her mother be uplift in consequence. kitty beighton take matter more calmly. it be pleasant to be single out by a commissioner with letter after his name and to fill the heart of other girl with bad feeling. but there be no deny the fact that barr saggott be phenomenally ugly. and all his attempt to adorn himself only make him more grotesque. he be not christen the langur which mean gray ape for nothing. it be pleasant kitty think to have him at her foot but it be good to escape from him and ride with the graceless cubbon the man in a dragoon regiment at umballa the boy with a handsome face and no prospect. kitty like cubbon more than a little. he never pretend for a moment the he be anything le than head over heel in love with her. for he be an honest boy. so kitty flee now and again from the stately wooing of barr saggott to the company of young cubbon and be scold by her mamma in consequence. but mother she say mr. saggott be such such a be so fearfully ugly you know. 
my dear say mr. beighton piously we cannot be other than an all rule providence ha make u. besides you will take precedence of your own mother you know. think of that and be reasonable. 
then kitty put up her little chin and say irreverent thing about precedence and commissioner and matrimony. mr. beighton rub the top of his head. for he be an easy go man. 
late in the season when he judge that the time be ripe barr saggott develop a plan which do great credit to his administrative power. he arrange an archery tournament for lady with a most sumptuous diamond stud bracelet a prize. 
he draw up his term skilfully and every one saw that the bracelet be a gift to miss beighton. the acceptance carry with it the hand and the heart of commissioner barr saggott. the term be a st. leonard s round thirty six shot at sixty yard under the rule of the simla toxophilite society. 
all simla be invite. there be beautifully arrange tea table under the deodar at annandale where the grand stand be now. and alone in it glory wink in the sun sit the diamond bracelet in a blue velvet case. miss beighton be anxious almost too anxious to compete. on the appoint afternoon all simla ride down to annandale to witness the judgment of paris turn upside down. 
kitty ride with young cubbon and it be easy to see that the boy be trouble in his mind. he must be hold innocent of everything that follow. kitty be pale and nervous and look long at the bracelet. barr saggott be gorgeously dress even more nervous than kitty and more hideous than ever. 
mr. beighton smile condescendingly a befit the mother of a potential commissioneress and the shoot begin. all the world stand in a semicircle a the lady come out one after the other. 
nothing be so tedious a an archery competition. they shoot and they shoot and they keep on shoot till the sun leave the valley and little breeze get up in the deodar and people wait for miss beighton to shoot and win. cubbon be at one horn of the semicircle round the shooter and barr saggott at the other. miss beighton be last on the list. the score have be weak and the bracelet plus commissioner barr saggott be hers to a certainty. 
the commissioner string her bow with his own sacred hand. she step forward look at the bracelet and her first arrow go true to a hair full into the heart of the gold count nine point. 
young cubbon on the leave turn white and his devil prompt barr saggott to smile. now horse use to shy when barr saggott smile. 
kitty saw that smile. she look to her leave front give an almost imperceptible nod to cubbon and go on shoot. 
i wish i could describe the scene that follow. it be out of the ordinary and most improper. miss kitty fit her arrow with immense deliberation so that every one might see what she be do. she be a perfect shoot. and her pound bow suit her to a nicety. she pin the wooden leg of the target with great care four successive time. she pin the wooden top of the target once and all the lady look at each other. then she begin some fancy shoot at the white which if you hit it count exactly one point. she put five arrow into the white. it be wonderful archery. but see that her business be to make gold and win the bracelet barr saggott turn a delicate green like young water grass. next she shoot over the target twice then wide to the leave twice always with the same deliberation while a chilly hush fell over the company and mr. beighton take out her handkerchief. then kitty shoot at the grind in front of the target and split several arrow. then she make a red or seven point just to show what she could do if she like and finish up her amaze performance with some more fancy shoot at the target support. here be her score a it be pick off. 
gold. red. blue. black. white. total hit. total score miss beighton. 
barr saggott look a if the last few arrowhead have be drive into his leg instead of the target s and the deep stillness be break by a little snubby mottle half grow girl say in a shrill voice of triumph. then i ve win. 
mr. beighton do her best to bear up. but she weep in the presence of the people. no train could help her through such a disappointment. kitty unstring her bow with a vicious jerk and go back to her place while barr saggott be try to pretend that he enjoy snap the bracelet on the snubby girl s raw red wrist. it be an awkward scene most awkward. every one try to depart in a body and leave kitty to the mercy of her mamma. 
but cubbon take her away instead and the rest isn t worth print.

if you go straight away from levee and government house list past trade ball far beyond everything and everybody you ever know in your respectable life you cross in time the border line where the last drop of white blood end and the full tide of black set in. it would be easy to talk to a new make duchess on the spur of the moment than to the borderline folk without violate some of their convention or hurt their feeling. the black and the white mix very quaintly in their way. sometimes the white show in spurt of fierce childish pride which be pride of race run crook and sometimes the black in still fierce abasement and humility half heathenish custom and strange unaccountable impulse to crime. one of these day this people understand they be far low than the class whence derozio the man who imitate byron spring will turn out a writer or a poet. and then we shall know how they live and what they feel. in the meantime any story about them cannot be absolutely correct in fact or inference. 
miss vezzis come from across the borderline to look after some child who belong to a lady until a regularly ordain nurse could come out. the lady say miss vezzis be a bad dirty nurse and inattentive. it never strike her that miss vezzis have her own life to lead and her own affair to worry over and that these affair be the most important thing in the world to miss vezzis. 
very few mistress admit this sort of reason. miss vezzis be a black a a boot and to our standard of taste hideously ugly. 
she wear cotton print gown and bulge shoe. and when she lose her temper with the child she abuse them in the language of the borderline which be part english part portuguese and part native. she be not attractive. but she have her pride and she prefer be call miss vezzis. 
every sunday she dress herself wonderfully and go to see her mamma who live for the most part on an old cane chair in a greasy tussur silk dress gown and a big rabbit warren of a house full of vezzises pereiras ribieras lisboa and gansalveses and a float population of loafer. besides fragment of the day s bazar garlic stale incense clothe throw on the floor petticoat hang on string for screen old bottle pewter crucifix dry immortelle pariah puppy plaster image of the virgin and hat without crown. miss vezzis draw twenty rupee a month for act a nurse and she squabble weekly with her mamma a to the percentage to be give towards housekeep. 
when the quarrel be over michele d cruze use to shamble across the low mud wall of the compound and make love to miss vezzis after the fashion of the borderline which be hedge about with much ceremony. michele be a poor sickly weed and very black. but he have his pride. he would not be see smoke a huqa for anything. and he look down on native a only a man with seven eighth native blood in his vein can. the vezzis family have their pride too. they trace their descent from a mythical plate layer who have work on the sone bridge when railway be new in india and they value their english origin. michele be a telegraph signaller on r. a month. the fact that he be in government employ make mr. vezzis lenient to the shortcoming of his ancestor. 
there be a compromise legend dom anna the tailor bring it from poonani that a black jew of cochin have once marry into the d cruze family. while it be an open secret that an uncle of mr. d cruze be at that very time do menial work connect with cook for a club in southern india. he send mr d cruze seven rupee eight anna a month. but she felt the disgrace to the family very keenly all the same. 
however in the course of a few sunday mr. vezzis bring herself to overlook these blemish and give her consent to the marriage of her daughter with michele on condition that michele should have at least fifty rupee a month to start marry life upon. this wonderful prudence must have be a linger touch of the mythical plate layer s yorkshire blood. for across the borderline people take a pride in marry when they please not when they can. 
have regard to his departmental prospect miss vezzis might a well have ask michele to go away and come back with the moon in his pocket. but michele be deeply in love with miss vezzis and that help him to endure. he accompany miss vezzis to mass one sunday and after mass walk home through the hot stale dust with her hand in his he swear by several saint whose name would not interest you never to forget miss vezzis. and she swear by her honor and the saint the oath run rather curiously. in nomine sanctissimae. whatever the name of the she saint be. and so forth end with a kiss on the forehead a kiss on the leave cheek and a kiss on the mouth never to forget michele. 
next week michele be transfer and miss vezzis drop tear upon the window sash of the intermediate compartment a he leave the station. 
if you look at the telegraph map of india you will see a long line skirt the coast from backergunge to madras. michele be order to tibasu a little sub office one third down this line to send message on from berhampur to chicacola and to think of miss vezzis and his chance of get fifty rupee a month out of office hour. he have the noise of the bay of bengal and a bengali babu for company. nothing more. he send foolish letter with cross tuck inside the flap of the envelope to miss vezzis. 
when he have be at tibasu for nearly three week his chance come. 
never forget that unless the outward and visible sign of our authority be always before a native he be a incapable a a child of understand what authority mean or where be the danger of disobey it. tibasu be a forget little place with a few orissa mohamedans in it. these hear nothing of the collector sahib for some time and heartily despise the hindu sub judge arrange to start a little mohurrum riot of their own. but the hindu turn out and break their head. when find lawlessness pleasant hindu and mahomedans together raise an aimless sort of donnybrook just to see how far they could go. they loot each other s shop and pay off private grudge in the regular way. it be a nasty little riot but not worth put in the newspaper. 
michele be work in his office when he hear the sound that a man never forget all his life the ah yah of an angry crowd. 
[when that sound drop about three tone and change to a thick drone ut the man who hear it have good go away if he be alone. ] the native police inspector run in and tell michele that the town be in an uproar and come to wreck the telegraph office. 
the babu put on his cap and quietly drop out of the window. while the police inspector afraid but obey the old race instinct which recognize a drop of white blood a far a it can be dilute say. what order doe the sahib give. 
the sahib decide michele. though horribly frighten he felt that for the hour he the man with the cochin jew and the menial uncle in his pedigree be the only representative of english authority in the place. then he think of miss vezzis and the fifty rupee and take the situation on himself. there be seven native policeman in tibasu and four crazy smooth bore musket among them. all the men be gray with fear but not beyond lead. michele drop the key of the telegraph instrument and go out at the head of his army to meet the mob. a the shout crew come round a corner of the road he drop and fire. the men behind him loose instinctively at the same time. 
the whole crowd cur to the backbone yell and run. leave one man dead and another die in the road. michele be sweat with fear but he keep his weakness under and go down into the town past the house where the sub judge have barricade himself. the street be empty. tibasu be more frighten than michele for the mob have be take at the right time. 
michele return to the telegraph office and send a message to chicacola ask for help. before an answer come he receive a deputation of the elder of tibasu tell him that the sub judge say his action generally be unconstitional and try to bully him. but the heart of michele d cruze be big and white in his breast because of his love for miss vezzis the nurse girl and because he have taste for the first time responsibility and success. those two make an intoxicate drink and have ruin more men than ever ha whiskey. michele answer that the sub judge might say what he please but until the assistant collector come the telegraph signaller be the government of india in tibasu and the elder of the town would be hold accountable for further riot. then they bow their head and say. show mercy. or word to that effect and go back in great fear. each accuse the other of have begin the riot. 
early in the dawn after a night s patrol with his seven policeman michele go down the road musket in hand to meet the assistant collector who have ride in to quell tibasu. but in the presence of this young englishman michele felt himself slip back more and more into the native and the tale of the tibasu riot end with the strain on the teller in an hysterical outburst of tear breed by sorrow that he have kill a man shame that he could not feel a uplift a he have felt through the night and childish anger that his tongue could not do justice to his great deed. it be the white drop in michele s vein die out though he do not know it. 
but the englishman understand. and after he have school those men of tibasu and have confer with the sub judge till that excellent official turn green he find time to draught an official letter describe the conduct of michele. which letter filter through the proper channel and end in the transfer of michele up country once more on the imperial salary of sixty six rupee a month. 
so he and miss vezzis be marry with great state and ancientry. and now there be several little d cruzes sprawl about the verandah of the central telegraph office. 
but if the whole revenue of the department he serf be to be his reward michele could never never repeat what he do at tibasu for the sake of miss vezzis the nurse girl.

watch of the night. 
what be in the brahmin s book that be in the brahmin s heart. neither you nor i know there be so much evil in the world. hindu proverb. 
this begin in a practical joke. but it ha go far enough now and be get serious. 
platte the subaltern be poor have a waterbury watch and a plain leather guard. 
the colonel have a waterbury watch also and for guard the lip strap of a curb chain. lip strap make the best watch guard. 
they be strong and short. between a lip strap and an ordinary leather guard there be no great difference. between one waterbury watch and another there be none at all. every one in the station know the colonel s lip strap. he be not a horsey man but he like people to believe he have be one once. and he weave fantastic story of the hunt bridle to which this particular lip strap have belong. otherwise he be painfully religious. 
platte and the colonel be dress at the club both late for their engagement and both in a hurry. that be kismet. the two watch be on a shelf below the look glass guard hang down. that be carelessness. platte change first snatch a watch look in the glass settle his tie and run. forty second late the colonel do exactly the same thing. each man take the other s watch. 
you may have notice that many religious people be deeply suspicious. they seem for purely religious purpose of course to know more about iniquity than the unregenerate. perhaps they be specially bad before they become convert. at any rate in the imputation of thing evil and in put the bad construction on thing innocent a certain type of good people may be trust to surpass all others. the colonel and his wife be of that type. but the colonel s wife be the bad. she manufacture the station scandal and talk to her ayah. nothing more need be say. the colonel s wife break up the laplace s home. the colonel s wife stop the ferris haughtrey engagement. the colonel s wife induce young buxton to keep his wife down in the plain through the first year of the marriage. whereby little mr. 
buxton die and the baby with her. these thing will be remember against the colonel s wife so long a there be a regiment in the country. 
but to come back to the colonel and platte. they go their several way from the dress room. the colonel din with two chaplain while platte go to a bachelor party and whist to follow. 
mark how thing happen. if platte s sais have put the new saddle pad on the mare the butt of the terrets would not have work through the wear leather and the old pad into the mare s wither when she be come home at two o clock in the morning. she would not have rear bolt fall into a ditch upset the cart and send platte fly over an aloe hedge on to mr. larkyn s well keep lawn. and this tale would never have be write. but the mare do all these thing and while platte be roll over and over on the turf like a shoot rabbit the watch and guard fly from his waistcoat a an infantry major s sword hop out of the scabbard when they be fire a feu de joie and roll and roll in the moonlight till it stop under a window. 
platte stuff his handkerchief under the pad put the cart straight and go home. 
mark again how kismet work. this would not happen once in a hundred year. towards the end of his dinner with the two chaplain the colonel let out his waistcoat and lean over the table to look at some mission report. the bar of the watch guard work through the buttonhole and the watch platte s watch slide quietly on to the carpet. where the bearer find it next morning and keep it. 
then the colonel go home to the wife of his bosom. but the driver of the carriage be drink and lose his way. so the colonel return at an unseemly hour and his excuse be not accept. if the colonel s wife have be an ordinary vessel of wrath appoint for destruction she would have know that when a man stay away on purpose his excuse be always sound and original. the very baldness of the colonel s explanation prove it truth. 
see once more the working of kismet. the colonel s watch which come with platte hurriedly on to mr. larkyn s lawn choose to stop just under mr. larkyn s window where she saw it early in the morning recognize it and pick it up. she have hear the crash of platte s cart at two o clock that morning and his voice call the mare name. she know platte and like him. that day she show him the watch and hear his story. he put his head on one side wink and say. how disgust. shock old man. with his religious train too. i should send the watch to the colonel s wife and ask for explanation. 
mr. larkyn think for a minute of the laplace whom she have know when laplace and his wife believe in each other and answer. i will send it. i think it will do her good. but remember we must never tell her the truth. 
platte guess that his own watch be in the colonel s possession and think that the return of the lip strap waterbury with a soothe note from mr. larkyn would merely create a small trouble for a few minute. mr. larkyn know good. she know that any poison drop would find good hold grind in the heart of the colonel s wife. 
the packet and a note contain a few remark on the colonel s call hour be send over to the colonel s wife who weep in her own room and take counsel with herself. 
if there be one woman under heaven whom the colonel s wife hat with holy fervor it be mr. larkyn. mr. larkyn be a frivolous lady and call the colonel s wife old cat. the colonel s wife say that somebody in revelation be remarkably like mr. larkyn. 
she mention other scripture people a well. from the old testament. [but the colonel s wife be the only person who care or dare to say anything against mr. larkyn. every one else accept her a an amuse honest little body. ] wherefore to believe that her husband have be shed watch under that thing s window at ungodly hour couple with the fact of his late arrival on the previous night be. 
at this point she rise up and seek her husband. he deny everything except the ownership of the watch. she beseech him for his soul s sake to speak the truth. he deny afresh with two bad word. then a stony silence hold the colonel s wife while a man could draw his breath five time. 
the speech that follow be no affair of mine or yours. it be make up of wifely and womanly jealousy. knowledge of old age and sink cheek. deep mistrust bear of the text that say even little baby heart be a bad a they make them. rancorous hatred of mr. larkyn and the tenet of the creed of the colonel s wife s upbringing. 
over and above all be the damn lip strap waterbury tick away in the palm of her shake wither hand. at that hour i think the colonel s wife realize a little of the restless suspicion she have inject into old laplace s mind a little of poor miss haughtrey s misery and some of the canker that eat into buxton s heart a he watch his wife die before his eye. the colonel stammer and try to explain. then he remember that his watch have disappear. and the mystery grow great. the colonel s wife talk and pray by turn till she be tire and go away to devise mean for chasten the stubborn heart of her husband. which translate mean in our slang tail twist. 
you see be deeply impress with the doctrine of original sin she could not believe in the face of appearance. she know too much and jump to the wild conclusion. 
but it be good for her. it spoil her life a she have spoil the life of the laplace. she have lose her faith in the colonel and here the creed suspicion come in he might she argue have err many time before a merciful providence at the hand of so unworthy an instrument a mr. larkyn have establish his guilt. 
he be a bad wicked gray haired profligate. this may sound too sudden a revulsion for a long wed wife. but it be a venerable fact that if a man or woman make a practice of and take a delight in believe and spread evil of people indifferent to him or her he or she will end in believe evil of folk very near and dear. you may think also that the mere incident of the watch be too small and trivial to raise this misunderstand. it be another age fact that in life a well a race all the bad accident happen at little ditch and cut down fence. in the same way you sometimes see a woman who would have make a joan of arc in another century and climate thresh herself to piece over all the mean worry of housekeep. but that be another story. 
her belief only make the colonel s wife more wretched because it insist so strongly on the villainy of men. remember what she have do it be pleasant to watch her unhappiness and the penny farthing attempt she make to hide it from the station. but the station know and laugh heartlessly. for they have hear the story of the watch with much dramatic gesture from mr. larkyn s lip.

but platte be quite right when he say that the joke have go too far. the mistrust and the tragedy of it which we outsider cannot see and do not believe in be kill the colonel s wife and be make the colonel wretched. if either of them read this story they can depend upon it be a fairly true account of the case and can kiss and make friend. 
shakespeare allude to the pleasure of watch an engineer be shell by his own battery. now this show that poet should not write about what they do not understand. any one could have tell him that sapper and gunner be perfectly different branch of the service. but if you correct the sentence and substitute gunner for sapper the moral come just the same. 
the other man. 
when the earth be sick and the sky be gray and the wood be rot with rain the dead man ride through the autumn day to visit his love again. old ballad. 
far back in the seventy before they have build any public office at simla and the broad road round jakko live in a pigeon hole in the p. w. d. hovel her parent make miss gaurey marry colonel schreiderling. he could not have be much more than thirty five year her senior. and a he live on two hundred rupee a month and have money of his own he be well off. he belong to good people and suffer in the cold weather from lung complaint. in the hot weather he dangle on the brink of heat apoplexy. but it never quite kill him. 
understand i do not blame schreiderling. he be a good husband accord to his light and his temper only fail him when he be be nurse. which be some seventeen day in each month. he be almost generous to his wife about money matter and that for him be a concession. still mr. schreiderling be not happy. they marry her when she be this side of twenty and have give all her poor little heart to another man. i have forget his name but we will call him the other man. he have no money and no prospect. 
he be not even good look. and i think he be in the commissariat or transport. but in spite of all these thing she love him very madly. and there be some sort of an engagement between the two when schreiderling appear and tell mr. gaurey that he wish to marry her daughter. then the other engagement be break off wash away by mr. gaurey s tear for that lady govern her house by weep over disobedience to her authority and the lack of reverence she receive in her old age. the daughter do not take after her mother. she never cry. not even at the wed. 
the other man bore his loss quietly and be transfer to a bad a station a he could find. perhaps the climate console him. he suffer from intermittent fever and that may have distract him from his other trouble. he be weak about the heart also. both way. one of the valve be affect and the fever make it bad. 
this show itself late on. 
then many month pass and mr. schreiderling take to be ill. 
she do not pine away like people in story book but she seem to pick up every form of illness that go about a station from simple fever upwards. she be never more than ordinarily pretty at the best of time. and the illness make her ugly. schreiderling say so. he pride himself on speak his mind. 
when she cease be pretty he leave her to her own device and go back to the lair of his bachelordom. she use to trot up and down simla mall in a forlorn sort of way with a gray terai hat well on the back of her head and a shock bad saddle under her. 
schreiderling s generosity stop at the horse. he say that any saddle would do for a woman a nervous a mr. schreiderling. she never be ask to dance because she do not dance well. and she be so dull and uninteresting that her box very seldom have any card in it. schreiderling say that if he have know that she be go to be such a scare crow after her marriage he would never have marry her. he always pride himself on speak his mind do schreiderling. 
he leave her at simla one august and go down to his regiment. 
then she revive a little but she never recover her look. i find out at the club that the other man be come up sick very sick on an off chance of recovery. the fever and the heart valve have nearly kill him. she know that too and she know what i have no interest in know when he be come up. i suppose he write to tell her. they have not see each other since a month before the wed. and here come the unpleasant part of the story. 
a late call keep me down at the dovedell hotel till dusk one even. mr. schreidlerling have be flit up and down the mall all the afternoon in the rain. come up along the cart road a tonga pass me and my pony tire with stand so long set off at a canter. just by the road down to the tonga office mr. schreiderling drip from head to foot be wait for the tonga. i turn up hill a the tonga be no affair of mine. and just then she begin to shriek. i go back at once and saw under the tonga office lamp mr. schreiderling kneel in the wet road by the back seat of the newly arrive tonga scream hideously. 
then she fell face down in the dirt a i come up. 
sit in the back seat very square and firm with one hand on the awning stanchion and the wet pour off his hat and moustache be the other man dead. the sixty mile up hill jolt have be too much for his valve i suppose. the tonga driver say. the sahib die two stage out of solon. therefore i tie him with a rope l he should fall out by the way and so come to simla. will the sahib give me bukshish. it point to the other man should have give one rupee. 
the other man sit with a grin on his face a if he enjoy the joke of his arrival. and mr. schreiderling in the mud begin to groan. there be no one except u four in the office and it be rain heavily. the first thing be to take mr. schreiderling home and the second be to prevent her name from be mix up with the affair. the tonga driver receive five rupee to find a bazar rickshaw for mr. schreiderling. he be to tell the tonga babu afterwards of the other man and the babu be to make such arrangement a seem best. 
mr. schreiderling be carry into the shed out of the rain and for three quarter of an hour we two wait for the rickshaw. the other man be leave exactly a he have arrive. mr. schreiderling would do everything but cry which might have help her. she try to scream a soon a her sens come back and then she begin pray for the other man s soul. have she not be a honest a the day she would have pray for her own soul too. i wait to hear her do this but she do not. then i try to get some of the mud off her habit. lastly the rickshaw come and i get her away partly by force. it be a terrible business from begin to end. but most of all when the rickshaw have to squeeze between the wall and the tonga and she saw by the lamp light that thin yellow hand grasp the awning stanchion. 
she be take home just a every one be go to a dance at viceregal lodge peterhoff it be then and the doctor find that she have fall from her horse that i have pick her up at the back of jakko and really deserve great credit for the prompt manner in which i have secure medical aid. she do not die men of schreiderling s stamp marry woman who don t die easily. they live and grow ugly. 
she never tell of her one meet since her marriage with the other man. and when the chill and cough follow the exposure of that even allow her abroad she never by word or sign allude to have meet me by the tonga office. perhaps she never know. 
she use to trot up and down the mall on that shock bad saddle look a if she expect to meet some one round the corner every minute. two year afterward she go home and die at bournemouth i think. 
schreiderling when he grow maudlin at mess use to talk about my poor dear wife. he always set great store on speak his mind do schreiderling.

tarrion come from goodness know where all away and away in some forsake part of central india where they call pachmari a sanitarium and drive behind trot bullock i believe. he belong to a regiment. but what he really want to do be to escape from his regiment and live in simla forever and ever. he have no preference for anything in particular beyond a good horse and a nice partner. he think he could do everything well. which be a beautiful belief when you hold it with all your heart. he be clever in many way and good to look at and always make people round him comfortable even in central india.

all viceroy when they first come out pas through the diplomatic secrecy craze. it wear off in time. but they all catch it in the begin because they be new to the country.
