dear mafflin you will remember that i write this story a an awful warn. none the le you have see fit to disregard it and have follow gadsby s example a i bet you would. i acknowledge that you pay the money at once but you have prejudice the mind of mr. mafflin against myself for though i be almost the only respectable friend of your bachelor day she ha be darwaza band to me throughout the season. further she cause you to invite me to dinner at the club where you call me a wild as of the desert and go home at half past ten after discourse for twenty minute on the responsibility of housekeep. you now drive a mail phaeton and sit under a church of england clergyman. i be not angry jack. it be your kismet a it be gaddy s and his kismet who can avoid. do not think that i be move by a spirit of revenge a i write thus publicly that you and you alone be responsible for this book. in other and more expansive day when you could look at a magnum without flush and at a cheroot without turn white you supply me with most of the material. take it back again would that i could have preserve your fetterless speech in the tell take it back and by your slippered hearth read it to the late miss deercourt. she will not be any the more will to receive my card but she will admire you immensely and you i feel sure will love me. you may even invite me to another very bad dinner at the club which a you and your wife know be a safe neutral grind for the entertainment of wild ass. then my very dear hypocrite we shall be quit. 
yours always. 
rudyard kipling. 
p. s. on second thought i should recommend you to keep the book away from mr. mafflin.

this be the end of the story of the gadsbys.

bimi. 
the orangoutang in the big iron cage lash to the sheep pen begin the discussion. the night be stiflingly hot and a han breitmann and i pass him drag our bed to the fore peak of the steamer he rouse himself and chatter obscenely. he have be catch somewhere in the malayan archipelago and be go to england to be exhibit at a shill a head. for four day he have struggle yell and wrench at the heavy iron bar of his prison without cease and have nearly slay a lascar incautious enough to come within reach of the great hairy paw. 
it would he well for you mine friend if you be a liddle seasick say han breitmann pause by the cage. you haf too much ego in your cosmos. 
the orangoutang s arm slide out negligently from between the bar. no one would have believe that it would make a sudden snake like rush at the german s breast. the thin silk of the sleep suit tear out. han step back unconcernedly to pluck a banana from a bunch hang close to one of the boat. 
too much ego say he peel the fruit and offer it to the cage devil who be rend the silk to tatter. 
then we lay out our bed in the bow among the sleep lascar to catch any breeze that the pace of the ship might give u. the sea be like smoky oil except where it turn to fire under our forefoot and whirl back into the dark in smear of dull flame. there be a thunderstorm some mile away. we could see the glimmer of the lightning. the ship s cow distress by the heat and the smell of the ape beast in the cage low unhappily from time to time in exactly the same key a the lookout man at the bow answer the hourly call from the bridge. the trample tune of the engine be very distinct and the jar of the ash lift a it be tip into the sea hurt the procession of hush noise. han lay down by my side and light a good night cigar. this be naturally the begin of conversation. he own a voice a soothe a the wash of the sea and store of experience a vast a the sea itself. for his business in life be to wander up and down the world collect orchid and wild beast and ethnological specimen for german and american dealer. i watch the glow end of his cigar wax and wane in the gloom a the sentence rise and fell till i be nearly asleep. the orangoutang trouble by some dream of the forest of his freedom begin to yell like a soul in purgatory and to wrench madly at the bar of the cage. 
if he be out now dere would not be much of u leave hereabouts say han lazily. he scream good. see now how i shall tame him when he stop himself. 
there be a pause in the outcry and from han mouth come an imitation of a snake s hiss so perfect that i almost spring to my foot. the sustain murderous sound run along the deck and the wrench at the bar cease. the orangoutang be quake in an ecstasy of pure terror. 
dot stop him say han. i learn dot trick in mogoung tanjong when i be collect liddle monkey for some people in berlin. efery one in d world be afraid of d monkey except d snake. so i blay snake against monkey and he keep quite still. dere be too much ego in his cosmos. dot be d soul custom of monkey. be you asleep or will you listen and i will tell a dale dot you shall not pelief. 
there s no tale in the wide world that i can t believe i say. 
if you have learn pelief you haf learn somedings. now i shall try your pelief. good. when i be collect dose liddle monkey it be in or und i be in d island of d archipelago over dere in d dark he point southward to new guinea generally mein gott. i would sooner collect life red devil than liddle monkey. when dey do not bite off your thumb dey be always die from nostalgia homesick for dey haf d imperfect soul which be midway arrest in defelopment und too much ego. i be dere for nearly a year und dere i find a man dot be call bertran. he be a frenchman und he be a goot man naturalist to the bone. dey say he be an escape convict but he be a naturalist und dot be enough for me. he would call all her life beast from d forest und dey would come. i say he be st. francis of assisi in a new dransmigration produce und he laugh und say he have never preach to d fish. he sell dem for trepang beche de m. 
und dot man who be king of beast tame men he have in d house shush such anoder a dot devil animal in d cage a great orangoutang dot think he be a man. he haf find him when he be a child d orangoutang und he be child and brother and opera comique all round to bertran. he have his room in dot house not a cage but a room mit a bed and sheet and he would go to bed and get up in d morning and smoke his cigar und eat his dinner mit bertran und walk mit him hand in hand which be most horrible. herr gott. i haf see dot beast throw himself back in his chair and laugh when bertran haf make fun of me. he be not a beast. he be a man and he talk to bertran und bertran comprehend for i bave see dem. und he be always politeful to me except when i talk too long to bertran und say nod at all to him. den he would pull me away dis great dark devil mit his enormous paw shush a if i be a child. he be not a beast he be a man. dis i saw pefore i know him three month und bertran he haf saw the same. and bimi d orangoutang haf understand u both mit his cigar between his big dog teeth und d blue gum. 
i be dere a year dere und at dere oder island somedimes for monkey and somedimes for butterfly und orchits. one time bertran say to me dot he will be marry because he ha find a girl dot be goot and he inquire if this marry idea be right. i would not say pecause it be not me dot be go to be marry. den he go off court d girl she be a half caste french girl very pretty. haf you get a new light for my cigar. oof. very pretty. only i say haf you think of bimi. if he pull me away when i talk to you what will he do to your wife. he will pull her in piece. if i be you bertran i would gif my wife for wed present d stuff figure of bimi. by dot time i bad learn somedings about d monkey people. shoot him. say bertran. he be your beast i say. if he be mine he would be shoot now. 
den i felt at d back of my neck d finger of bimi. mein gott. i tell you dot he talk through dose finger. it be d deaf and dumb alphabet all gomplete. he slide his hairy arm round my neck and he tilt up my chin and look into my face shust to see if i understand his talk so well a he understand mine. see now dere. say bertran und you would shoot him while he be cuddle you. dot be d teuton ingrate. 
but i know dot i have make bimi a life s enemy pecause his finger haf talk murder through the back of my neck. next dime i see bimi dere be a pistol in my belt und he touch it once and i open de breech to show him it be load. he haf see d liddle monkey kill in d wood and he understand. 
so bertran he be marry and he forget clean about bimi dot be skippin alone on the beach mit d haf of a human soul in his belly. i be see him skip und he take a big bough und thrash d sand till he haf make a great hole like a grave. so i say to bertran for any sake kill bimi. he be mad mit d jealousy. 
bertran haf say. he be not mad at all. he haf obey and love my wife und if she speak he will get her slipper und he look at his wife across d room. she be a very pretty girl.

dot next day bertran come to my house to help me make some wood case for d specimen und he tell me dot he haf leave his wife a liddle while mit bimi in d garden. den i finish my case quick und i say. let u go to your house und get a trink. he laugh und say. come along dry man.

namgay doola. 
once upon a time there be a king who live on the road to thibet very many mile in the himalaya mountain. his kingdom be foot above the sea and exactly four mile square but most of the mile stand on end owe to the nature of the country. his revenue be rather le than pound yearly and they be expend on the maintenance of one elephant and a stand army of five men. he be tributary to the indian government who allow him certain sum for keep a section of the himalaya thibet road in repair. he further increase his revenue by sell timber to the railway company for he would cut the great deodar tree in his own forest and they fell thunder into the sutlej river and be sweep down to the plain mile away and become railway tie. now and again this king whose name doe not matter would mount a ring streak horse and ride score of mile to simlatown to confer with the lieutenant governor on matter of state or assure the viceroy that his sword be at the service of the queen empress. then the viceroy would cause a ruffle of drum to be sound and the ring streak horse and the cavalry of the state two men in tatter and the herald who bore the silver stick before the king would trot back to their own place which be between the tail of a heaven climb glacier and a dark birch forest. 
now from such a king always remember that he possess one veritable elephant and could count his descent for year i expect when it be my fate to wander through his dominion no more than mere license to live. 
the night have close in rain and roll cloud blot out the light of the village in the valley. forty mile away untouched by cloud or storm the white shoulder of dongo pa the mountain of the council of the god uphold the even star. the monkey sing sorrowfully to each other a they hunt for dry root in the fern drape tree and the last puff of the day wind bring from the unseen village the scent of damp wood smoke hot cake drip undergrowth and rot pine cone. that smell be the true smell of the himalaya and if it once get into the blood of a man he will at the last forget everything else return to the hill to die. the cloud close and the smell go away and there remain nothing in all the world except chill white mist and the boom of the sutlej river. 
a fat tail sheep who do not want to die bleat lamentably at my tent door. he be scuffle with the prime minister and the director general of public education and he be a royal gift to me and my camp servant. i express my thank suitably and inquire if i might have audience of the king. the prime minister readjust his turban it have fall off in the struggle and assure me that the king would be very please to see me. therefore i dispatch two bottle a a foretaste and when the sheep have enter upon another incarnation climb up to the king s palace through the wet. he have send his army to escort me but it stay to talk with my cook. soldier be very much alike all the world over. 
the palace be a four room white wash mud and timber house the fine in all the hill for a day s journey. the king be dress in a purple velvet jacket white muslin trouser and a saffron yellow turban of price. he give me audience in a little carpet room open off the palace courtyard which be occupy by the elephant of state. the great beast be sheet and anchor from trunk to tail and the curve of his back stand out against the sky line. 
the prime minister and the director general of public instruction be present to introduce me. but all the court have be dismiss l the two bottle aforesaid should corrupt their moral. the king cast a wreath of heavy scent flower round my neck a i bow and inquire how my honor presence have the felicity to be. i say that through see his auspicious countenance the mist of the night have turn into sunshine and that by reason of his beneficent sheep his good deed would be remember by the god. he say that since i have set my magnificent foot in his kingdom the crop would probably yield seventy per cent more than the average. i say that the fame of the king have reach to the four corner of the earth and that the nation gnash their teeth when they hear daily of the glory of his realm and the wisdom of his moon like prime minister and lotus eye director general of public education. 
then we sit down on clean white cushion and i be at the king s right hand. three minute late he be tell me that the condition of the maize crop be something disgraceful and that the railway company would not pay him enough for his timber. the talk shift to and fro with the bottle. we discuss very many quaint thing and the king become confidential on the subject of government generally. most of all he dwell on the shortcoming of one of his subject who from what i could gather have be paralyze the executive. 
in the old day say the king i could have order the elephant yonder to trample him to death. now i must e en send him seventy mile across the hill to be try and his keep for that time would be upon the state. and the elephant eat everything. 
what be the man s crime rajah sahib. say i. 
firstly he be an outlander and no man of mine own people. secondly since of my favor i give him land upon his come he refuse to pay revenue. be i not the lord of the earth above and below entitle by right and custom to one eighth of the crop. yet this devil establish himself refuse to pay a single tax. and he bring a poisonous spawn of babe. 
cast him into jail i say. 
sahib the king answer shift a little on the cushion once and only once in these forty year sickness come upon me so that i be not able to go abroad. in that hour i make a vow to my god that i would never again cut man or woman from the light of the sun and the air of god for i perceive the nature of the punishment. how can i break my vow. be it only the lop off of a hand or a foot i should not delay. but even that be impossible now that the english have rule. one or another of my people he look obliquely at the director general of public education would at once write a letter to the viceroy and perhaps i should be deprive of that ruffle of drum. 
he unscrew the mouthpiece of his silver water pipe fit a plain amber one and pass the pipe to me. not content with refuse revenue he continue this outlander refuse also to beegar. this be the corvee or force labor on the road. and stir my people up to the like treason. yet he be if so he will an expert log snatcher. there be none good or bold among my people to clear a block of the river when the log stick fast. 
but he worship strange god say the prime minister deferentially. 
for that i have no concern say the king who be a tolerant a akbar in matter of belief. to each man his own god and the fire or mother earth for u all at the last. it be the rebellion that offend me. 
the king ha an army i suggest. ha not the king burn the man s house and leave him naked to the night dew. 
nay. a hut be a hut and it hold the life of a man. but once i send my army against him when his excuse become wearisome. of their head he brake three across the top with a stick. the other two men run away. also the gun would not shoot. 
i have see the equipment of the infantry. one third of it be an old muzzle load fowl piece with rag rust hole where the nipple should have be. one third a wirebound matchlock with a worm eat stock and one third a four bore flint duck gun without a flint. 
but it be to be remember say the king reach out for the bottle that he be a very expert log snatcher and a man of a merry face. what shall i do to him sahib. 
this be interest. the timid hill folk would a soon have refuse tax to their king a offering to their god. the rebel must be a man of character. 
if it be the king s permission i say i will not strike my tent till the third day and i will see this man. the mercy of the king be godlike and rebellion be like unto the sin of witchcraft. moreover both the bottle and another be empty. 
you have my leave to go say the king. 
next morning the crier go through the stare proclaim that there be a log jam on the river and that it behoove all loyal subject to clear it. the people pour down from their village to the moist warm valley of poppy field and the king and i go with them. 
hundred of dress deodar log have catch on a snag of rock and the river be bring down more log every minute to complete the blockade. the water snarl and wrench and worry at the timber while the population of the state prod at the near log with pole in the hope of ease the pressure. then there go up a shout of namgay doola. namgay doola. and a large red haired villager hurry up strip off his clothe a he run. 
that he be. that be the rebel. say the king. now will the dam be clear.

from thibet. he point across the hill and grin. that grin go straight to my heart. mechanically i hold out my hand and namgay doola take it. no pure thibetan would have understand the mean of the gesture. he go away to look for his clothe and a he climb back to his village i hear a joyous yell that seem unaccountably familiar. it be the whoop of namgay doola.

it be that king s custom to judge his subject every day between eleven and three o clock. i hear him do justice equitably on weighty matter of trespass slander and a little wife steal. then his brow cloud and he summon me.

dir hane mard i yemen dir to weeree ala gee.

i know that breed. 
the recrudescence of imray. 
imray have achieve the impossible. without warn for no conceivable motive in his youth and at the threshold of his career he have choose to disappear from the world which be to say the little indian station where he live. upon a day he be alive well happy and in great evidence at his club among the billiard table. upon a morning he be not and no manner of search could make sure where he might be. he have step out of his place. he have not appear at his office at the proper time and his dog cart be not upon the public road. for these reason and because he be hamper in a microscopical degree the administration of the indian empire the indian empire pause for one microscopical moment to make inquiry into the fate of imray. pond be drag well be plumb telegram be dispatch down the line of railway and to the near seaport town mile away but imray be not at the end of the drag rope nor the telegram. he be go and his place know him no more. then the work of the great indian empire sweep forward because it could not be delay and imray from be a man become a mystery such a thing a men talk over at their table in the club for a month and then forget utterly. his gun horse and cart be sell to the high bidder. his superior officer write an absurd letter to his mother say that imray have unaccountably disappear and his bungalow stand empty on the road. 
after three or four month of the scorch hot weather have go by my friend strickland of the police force saw fit to rent the bungalow from the native landlord. this be before he be engage to miss youghal an affair which ha be describe in another place and while he be pursue his investigation into native life. his own life be sufficiently peculiar and men complain of his manner and custom. there be always food in his house but there be no regular time for meal. he eat stand up and walk about whatever he might find on the sideboard and this be not good for the inside of human being. his domestic equipment be limit to six rifle three shotgun five saddle and a collection of stiff joint masheer rod big and strong than the large salmon rod. these thing occupy one half of his bungalow and the other half be give up to strickland and his dog tietjens an enormous rampur slut who sing when she be order and devour daily the ration of two men. she speak to strickland in a language of her own and whenever in her walk abroad she saw thing calculate to destroy the peace of her majesty the queen empress she return to her master and give him information. strickland would take step at once and the end of his labor be trouble and fine and imprisonment for other people. the native believe that tietjens be a familiar spirit and treat her with the great reverence that be bear of hate and fear one room in the bungalow be set apart for her special use. she own a bedstead a blanket and a drink trough and if any one come into strickland s room at night her custom be to knock down the invader and give tongue till some one come with a light. strickland owe his life to her. when he be on the frontier in search of the local murderer who come in the grey dawn to send strickland much further than the andaman island tietjens catch him a he be crawl into strickland s tent with a dagger between his teeth and after his record of iniquity be establish in the eye of the law he be hang. from that date tietjens wear a collar of rough silver and employ a monogram on her night blanket and the blanket be double weave kashmir cloth for she be a delicate dog. 
under no circumstance would she be separate from strickland and when he be ill with fever she make great trouble for the doctor because she do not know how to help her master and would not allow another creature to attempt aid. macarnaght of the indian medical service beat her over the head with a gun before she could understand that she must give room for those who could give quinine. 
a short time after strickland have take imray s bungalow my business take me through that station and naturally the club quarter be full i quarter myself upon strickland. it be a desirable bungalow eight room and heavily thatch against any chance of leakage from rain. under the pitch of the roof run a ceiling cloth which look just a nice a a whitewash ceiling. the landlord have repaint it when strickland take the bungalow and unless you know how indian bungalow be build you would never have suspect that above the cloth lay the dark three corner cavern of the roof where the beam and the under side of the thatch harbor all manner of rat hat ant and other thing. 
tietjens meet me in the veranda with a bay like the boom of the bell of st. paul s and put her paw on my shoulder and say she be glad to see me. strickland have contrive to put together that sort of meal which he call lunch and immediately after it be finish go out about his business. i be leave alone with tietjens and my own affair. the heat of the summer have break up and give place to the warm damp of the rain. there be no motion in the heat air but the rain fell like bayonet rod on the earth and fling up a blue mist where it splash back again. the bamboo and the custard apple the poinsettia and the mango tree in the garden stand still while the warm water lash through them and the frog begin to sing among the aloe hedge. a little before the light fail and when the rain be at it bad i sit in the back veranda and hear the water roar from the eaves and scratch myself because i be cover with the thing they call prickly heat. tietjens come out with me and put her head in my lap and be very sorrowful so i give her biscuit when tea be ready and i take tea in the back veranda on account of the little coolness i find there. the room of the house be dark behind me. i could smell strickland s saddlery and the oil on his gun and i do not the least desire to sit among these thing. my own servant come to me in the twilight the muslin of his clothe cling tightly to his drench body and tell me that a gentleman have call and wish to see some one. very much against my will and because of the darkness of the room i go into the naked draw room tell my man to bring the light. there might or might not have be a caller in the room it seem to me that i saw a figure by one of the window but when the light come there be nothing save the spike of the rain without and the smell of the drink earth in my nostril. i explain to my man that he be no wise than he ought to be and go back to the veranda to talk to tietjens. she have go out into the wet and i could hardly coax her back to me even with biscuit with sugar on top. strickland ride back drip wet just before dinner and the first thing he say be. 
ha any one call. 
i explain with apology that my servant have call me into the draw room on a false alarm. or that some loafer have try to call on strickland and think good of it flee after give his name. strickland order dinner without comment and since it be a real dinner with white tablecloth attach we sit down. 
at nine o clock strickland want to go to bed and i be tire too. tietjens who have be lie underneath the table rise up and go into the least expose veranda a soon a her master move to his own room which be next to the stately chamber set apart for tietjens. if a mere wife have wish to sleep out of door in that pelt rain it would not have matter but tietjens be a dog and therefore the good animal. i look at strickland expect to see him flog her with a whip. he smile queerly a a man would smile after tell some hideous domestic tragedy. she ha do this ever since i move in here. 
the dog be strickland s dog so i say nothing but i felt all that strickland felt in be make light of. tietjens encamp outside my bedroom window and storm after storm come up thunder on the thatch and die away. the lightning spatter the sky a a throw egg spatter a barn door but the light be pale blue not yellow. and look through my slit bamboo blind i could see the great dog stand not sleep in the veranda the hackle alift on her back and her foot plant a tensely a the draw wire rope of a suspension bridge. in the very short pause of the thunder i try to sleep but it seem that some one want me very badly. he whoever he be be try to call me by name but his voice be no more than a husky whisper. then the thunder cease and tietjens go into the garden and howl at the low moon. somebody try to open my door and walk about and through the house and stand breathe heavily in the veranda and just when i be fall asleep i fancy that i hear a wild hammer and clamor above my head or on the door. 
i run into strickland s room and ask him whether he be ill and have be call for me. he be lie on the bed half dress with a pipe in his mouth. i think you d come he say. have i be walk around the house at all. 
i explain that he have be in the din room and the smoke room and two or three other place. and he laugh and tell me to go back to bed. i go back to bed and sleep till the morning but in all my dream i be sure i be do some one an injustice in not attend to his want. what those want be i could not tell but a flutter whisper bolt fumble lure loiter some one be reproach me for my slackness and through all the dream i hear the howl of tietjens in the garden and the thrash of the rain. 
i be in that house for two day and strickland go to his office daily leave me alone for eight or ten hour a day with tietjens for my only companion. a long a the full light last i be comfortable and so be tietjens. but in the twilight she and i move into the back veranda and cuddle each other for company. we be alone in the house but for all that it be fully occupy by a tenant with whom i have no desire to interfere. i never saw him but i could see the curtain between the room quiver where he have just pass through. i could hear the chair creak a the bamboo spring under a weight that have just quit them. and i could feel when i go to get a book from the din room that somebody be wait in the shadow of the front veranda till i should have go away. tietjens make the twilight more interest by glare into the darken room with every hair erect and follow the motion of something that i could not see. she never enter the room but her eye move and that be quite sufficient. only when my servant come to trim the lamp and make all light and habitable she would come in with me and spend her time sit on her haunch watch an invisible extra man a he move about behind my shoulder. dog be cheerful companion. 
i explain to strickland gently a might be that i would go over to the club and find for myself quarter there. i admire his hospitality be please with his gun and rod but i do not much care for his house and it atmosphere. he hear me out to the end and then smile very wearily but without contempt for he be a man who understand thing. stay on he say and see what this thing mean. all you have talk about i have know since i take the bungalow. stay on and wait. tietjens ha leave me. be you go too. 
i have see him through one little affair connect with an idol that have bring me to the door of a lunatic asylum and i have no desire to help him through further experience. he be a man to whom unpleasantness arrive a do dinner to ordinary people. 
therefore i explain more clearly than ever that i like him immensely and would he happy to see him in the daytime but that i didn t care to sleep under his roof. this be after dinner when tietjens have go out to lie in the veranda. 
pon my soul i don t wonder say strickland with his eye on the ceiling cloth. look at that. 
the tail of two snake be hang between the cloth and the cornice of the wall. they throw long shadow in the lamp light. if you be afraid of snake of course say strickland. i hate and fear snake because if you look into the eye of any snake you will see that it know all and more of man s fall and that it feel all the contempt that the devil felt when adam be evict from eden. besides which it bite be generally fatal and it burst up trouser leg. 
you ought to get your thatch over haul i say. give me a masheer rod and we ll poke em down. 
they ll hide among the roof beam say strickland. i can t stand snake overhead. i m go up. if i shake em down stand by with a clean rod and break their back. 
i be not anxious to assist strickland in his work hut i take the load rod and wait in the din room while strickland bring a gardener s ladder from the veranda and set it against the side of the room. the snake tail draw themselves up and disappear. we could hear the dry rush scuttle of long body run over the baggy cloth. strickland take a lamp with him while i try to make clear the danger of hunt roof snake between a ceiling cloth and a thatch apart from the deterioration of property cause by rip out ceiling cloth. 
n o n s en s e say strickland. they re sure to hide near the wall by the cloth. the brick be too cold for em and the heat of the room be just what they like. he put his hand to the corner of the cloth and rip the rotten stuff from the cornice. it give great sound of tear and strickland put his head through the open into the dark of the angle of the roof beam. i set my teeth and lift the load rod for i have not the least knowledge of what might descend. 
h m say strickland. and his voice roll and rumble in the roof. there s room for another set of room up here and by jove. some one be occupy em. 
snake. i say down below. 
no. it s a buffalo. hand me up the two first joint of a masheer rod and i ll prod it. it s lie on the main beam. 
i hand up the rod. 
what a nest for owl and serpent. no wonder the snake live here say strickland climb further into the roof. i could see his elbow thrust with the rod. come out of that whoever you be. look out. head below there. it s totter. 
i saw the ceiling cloth nearly in the centre of the room bag with a shape that be press it downward and downward toward the light lamp on the table. i snatch a lamp out of danger and stand back. then the cloth rip out from the wall tear split sway and shoot down upon the table something that i dare not look at till strickland have slide down the ladder and be stand by my side. 
he do not say much be a man of few word but he pick up the loose end of the table cloth and throw it over the thing on the table. 
it strike me say he pull down the lamp our friend imray ha come back. oh. you would would you. 
there be a movement under the cloth and a little snake wriggle out to be back break by the butt of the masheer rod. i be sufficiently sick to make no remark worth record. 
strickland meditate and help himself to drink liberally. the thing under the cloth make no more sign of life. 
be it imray. i say. 
strickland turn back the cloth for a moment and look. it be imray he say and his throat be cut from ear to ear. 
then we speak both together and to ourselves. 
that s why he whisper about the house.

she sniff and be still. the break and tattered ceiling cloth hang down almost to the level of the table and there be hardly room to move away from the discovery. 
then tietjens come in and sit down her teeth bar and her forepaw plant. she look at strickland. 
it s bad business old lady say he. men don t go up into the roof of their bungalow to die and they don t fasten up the ceiling cloth behind em. let s think it out. 
let s think it out somewhere else i say. 
excellent idea. turn the lamp out. we ll get into my room. 
i do not turn the lamp out. i go into strickland s room first and allow him to make the darkness. then he follow me and we light tobacco and think. strickland do the think. i smoke furiously because i be afraid. 
imray be back say strickland. the question be who kill imray. don t talk i have a notion of my own. when i take this bungalow i take most of imray s servant. imray be guileless and inoffensive wasn t he. 
i agree though the heap under the cloth look neither one thing nor the other. 
if i call the servant they will stand fast in a crowd and lie like aryan. what do you suggest. 
call em in one by one i say. 
they ll run away and give the news to all their fellow say strickland. 
we must segregate em. do you suppose your servant know anything about it. 
he may for aught i know hut i don t think it s likely. he ha only be here two or three day. 
what s your notion. i ask. 
i can t quite tell. how the dickens do the man get the wrong side of the ceiling cloth.

come in say strickland. it be a very warm night isn t it.

it will be so if god plea say strickland tug off his hoot. it be in my mind bahadur khan that i have work thee remorselessly for many day ever since that time when thou first come into my service. what time be that. 
ha the heaven bear forget. it be when imray sahib go secretly to europe without warn give and i even i come into the honor service of the protector of the poor. 
and imray sahib go to europe. 
it be so say among the servant. 
and thou wilt take service with him when he return. 
assuredly sahib. he be a good master and cherish his dependent. 
that be true. i be very tire but i can go buck shoot tomorrow. give me the little rifle that i use for black buck. it be in the case yonder.

moti guj mutineer. 
once upon a time there be a coffee planter in india who wish to clear some forest land for coffee plant. when he have cut down all the tree and burn the underwood the stump still remain. dynamite be expensive and slow fire slow. the happy medium for stump clear be the lord of all beast who be the elephant. he will either push the stump out of the grind with his tusk if he ha any or drag it out with rope. the planter therefore hire elephant by one and two and three and fell to work. the very best of all the elephant belong to the very bad of all the driver or mahout. and this superior beast s name be moti guj. he be the absolute property of his mahout which would never have be the case under native rule. for moti guj be a creature to be desire by king and his name be translate mean the pearl elephant. because the british government be in the land deesa the mahout enjoy his property undisturbed. he be dissipate. when he have make much money through the strength of his elephant he would get extremely drink and give moti guj a beat with a tent peg over the tender nail of the forefoot. moti guj never trample the life out of deesa on these occasion for he know that after the beat be over deesa would embrace his trunk and weep and call him his love and his life and the liver of his soul and give him some liquor. moti guj be very fond of liquor arrack for choice though he would drink palm tree toddy if nothing good offer. then deesa would go to sleep between moti guj s forefoot and a deesa generally choose the middle of the public road and a moti guj mount guard over him and would not permit horse foot or cart to pas by traffic be congest till deesa saw fit to wake up. 
there be no sleep in the daytime on the planter s clear. the wage be too high to risk. deesa sit on moti guj s neck and give him order while moti guj root up the stump for he own a magnificent pair of tusk. or pull at the end of a rope for he have a magnificent pair of shoulder while deesa kick him behind the ear and say he be the king of elephant. at even time moti guj would wash down his three hundred pound weight of green food with a quart of arrack and deesa would take a share and sing song between moti guj s leg till it be time to go to bed. once a week deesa lead moti guj down to the river and moti gui lay on his side luxuriously in the shallow while deesa go over him with a coir swab and a brick. moti guj never mistake the pound blow of the latter for the smack of the former that warn him to get up and turn over on the other side. then deesa would look at his foot and examine his eye and turn up the fringe of his mighty ear in case of sore or bud ophthalmia. after inspection the two would come up with a song from the sea moti guj all black and shin wave a tear tree branch twelve foot long in his trunk and deesa knot up his own long wet hair. 
it be a peaceful well pay life till deesa felt the return of the desire to drink deep. he wish for an orgy. the little draught that lead nowhere be take the manhood out of him. 
he go to the planter and my mother s dead say he weep. 
she die on the last plantation two month ago and she die once before that when you be work for me last year say the planter who know something of the way of nativedom. 
then it s my aunt and she be just the same a a mother to me say deesa weep more than ever. she ha leave eighteen small child entirely without bread and it be i who must fill their little stomach say deesa beat his head on the floor. 
who bring the news. say the planter. 
the post say deesa. 
there hasn t be a post here for the past week. get back to your line. 
a devastate sickness ha fall on my village and all my wife be die yell deesa really in tear this time. 
call chihun who come from deesa s village say the planter. chihun ha this man get a wife. 
he. say chihun. no. not a woman of our village would look at him. they d sooner marry the elephant. 
chihun snort. deesa weep and bellow. 
you will get into a difficulty in a minute say the planter. go back to your work. 
now i will speak heaven s truth gulp deesa with an inspiration. i haven t be drink for two month. i desire to depart in order to get properly drink afar off and distant from this heavenly plantation. thus i shall cause no trouble. 
a flicker smile cross the planter s face. deesa say he you ve speak the truth and i d give you leave on the spot if anything could be do with moti guj while you re away. you know that he will only obey your order. 
may the light of the heaven live forty thousand year. i shall be absent but ten little day. after that upon my faith and honor and soul i return. a to the inconsiderable interval have i the gracious permission of the heaven bear to call up moti guj. 
permission be grant and in answer of deesa s shrill yell the mighty tusker swing out of the shade of a clump of tree where he have be squirt dust over himself till his master should return. 
light of my heart protector of the drunken mountain of might give ear. say deesa stand in front of him. 
moti guj give ear and salute with his trunk. i be go away say deesa. 
moti guj s eye twinkle. he like jaunt a well a his master. one could snatch all manner of nice thing from the roadside then. 
but you you fussy old pig must stay behind and work. 
the twinkle die out a moti guj try to look delight. he hat stump haul on the plantation. it hurt his teeth. 
i shall be go for ten day oh delectable one. hold up your near forefoot and i ll impress the fact upon it warty toad of a dry mud puddle. deesa take a tent peg and bang moti guj ten time on the nail. moti guj grunt and shuffle from foot to foot. 
ten day say deesa you will work and haul and root the tree a chihun here shall order you. take up chihun and set him on your neck. moti guj curl the tip of his trunk chihun put his foot there and be swing on to the neck. deesa hand chihun the heavy ankus the iron elephant goad. 
chihun thump moti guj s bald head a a paver thump a curbstone. 
moti guj trumpet. 
be still hog of the backwoods. chihun s your mahout for ten day. and now bid me goodbye beast after mine own heart. oh my lord my king. jewel of all create elephant lily of the herd preserve your honor health. be virtuous. adieu. 
moti guj lap his trunk round deesa and swing him into the air twice. that be his way of bid him goodbye. 
he ll work now say deesa to the planter. have i leave to go. 
the planter nod and deesa dive into the wood. moti guj go back to haul stump. 
chihun be very kind to him but he felt unhappy and forlorn for all that. chihun give him a ball of spice and tickle him under the chin and chihun s little baby coo to him after work be over. and chihun s wife call him a darling. but moti guj be a bachelor by instinct a deesa be. he do not understand the domestic emotion. he want the light of his universe back again the drink and the drunken slumber the savage beating and the savage caress. 
none the le he work well and the planter wonder. deesa have wander along the road till he meet a marriage procession of his own caste and drink dance and tipple have drift with it past all knowledge of the lapse of time. 
the morning of the eleventh day dawn and there return no deesa moti guj be loose from his rope for the daily stint. he swing clear look round shrug his shoulder and begin to walk away a one have business elsewhere. 
hi. ho. come back you. shout chihun. come back and put me on your neck misborn mountain. return splendor of the hillside. adornment of all india heave to or i ll bang every toe off your forefoot. 
moti guj gurgle gently but do not obey. chihun run after him with a rope and catch him up. moti guj put his ear forward and chihun know what that mean though he try to carry it off with high word. 
none of your nonsense with me say he. to your picket devil son. 
hrrump. say moti guj and that be all that and the forebent ear. 
moti guj put his hand in his pocket chew a branch for a toothpick and stroll about the clear make fun of the other elephant who have just set to work. 
chihun report the state of affair to the planter who come out with a dog whip and crack it furiously. moti guj pay the white man the compliment of charge him nearly a quarter of a mile across the clear and hrrumphing him into his veranda. then he stand outside the house chuckle to himself and shake all over with the fun of it a an elephant will. 
we ll thrash him say the planter. he shall have the fine thrash ever elephant receive. give kala nag and nazim twelve foot of chain apiece and tell them to lay on twenty. 
kala nag which mean black snake and nazim be two of the big elephant in the line and one of their duty be to administer the grave punishment since no man can beat an elephant properly. 
they take the whip chain and rattle them in their trunk a they sidle up to moti guj mean to hustle him between them. moti guj have never in all his life of thirty nine year be whip and he do not intend to begin a new experience. so he wait wave his head from right to leave and measure the precise spot in kala nag s fat side where a blunt tusk could sink deep. kala nag have no tusk. the chain be the badge of his authority. but for all that he swing wide of moti guj at the last minute and try to appear a if he have bring the chain out for amusement. nazim turn round and go home early. he do not feel fight fit that morning and so moti guj be leave stand alone with his ear cock. 
that decide the planter to argue no more and moti guj roll back to his amateur inspection of the clear. an elephant who will not work and be not tie up be about a manageable a an eighty one ton gun loose in a heavy seaway. he slap old friend on the back and ask them if the stump be come away easily. he talk nonsense concern labor and the inalienable right of elephant to a long nooning. and wander to and fro he thoroughly demoralize the garden till sundown when he return to his picket for food. 
if you win t work you sha n t eat say chihun angrily. you re a wild elephant and no educate animal at all. go back to your jungle. 
chihun s little brown baby be roll on the floor of the hut and stretch out it fat arm to the huge shadow in the doorway. moti guj know well that it be the dear thing on earth to chihun. he swing out his trunk with a fascinate crook at the end and the brown baby throw itself shout upon it. moti guj make fast and pull up till the brown baby be crow in the air twelve foot above his father s head. 
great lord. say chihun. flour cake of the best twelve in number two foot across and soak in rum shall be yours on the instant and two hundred pound weight of fresh cut young sugar cane therewith. deign only to put down safely that insignificant brat who be my heart and my life to me. 
moti guj tuck the brown baby comfortably between his forefoot that could have knock into toothpick all chihun s hut and wait for his food. he eat it and the brown baby crawl away. moti guj doze and think of deesa. one of many mystery connect with the elephant be that his huge body need le sleep than anything else that life. four or five hour in the night suffice two just before midnight lie down on one side. two just after one o clock lie down on the other. the rest of the silent hour be fill with eat and fidget and long grumble soliloquy. 
at midnight therefore moti guj stride out of his picket for a think have come to him that deesa might be lie drink somewhere in the dark forest with none to look after him. so all that night he chase through the undergrowth blow and trumpet and shake his ear. he go down to the river and blare across the shallow where deesa use to wash him hut there be no answer. he could not find deesa but he disturb all the other elephant in the line and nearly frighten to death some gypsy in the wood. 
at dawn deesa return to the plantation. he have be very drink in deed and he expect to get into trouble for outstay his leave. he draw a long breath when he saw that the bungalow and the plantation be still uninjured for he know something of moti guj s temper and report himself with many lie and salaam. moti guj have go to his picket for breakfast. the night exercise have make him hungry. 
call up your beast say the planter. and deesa shout in the mysterious elephant language that some mahout believe come from china at the birth of the world when elephant and not men be master. moti guj hear and come. elephant do not gallop they move from place at vary rate of speed. if an elephant wish to catch an express train he could not gallop but he could catch the train. so moti guj be at the planter s door almost before chihun notice that he have leave his picket. he fell into deesa s arm trumpet with joy and the man and beast weep and slobber over each other and handle each other from head to heel to see that no harm have befall. 
now we will get to work say deesa. lift me up my son and my joy. 
moti guj swing him up and the two go to the coffee clear to look for difficult stump. 
the planter be too astonish to be very angry.
